    Person shall mean any individual, trustee, executor, other fiduciary, corporation, unincorporated association, partnership, sole proprietorship, company, firm, or other legal entity. 
    Short-term lease or rental shall mean any lease or rental of a vehicle that is not a long-term lease or rental. (G.S. 160A-215.1(e)(2) and G.S. 105-187.1(4)) 
    Tax collector shall refer to that individual appointed by the governing body pursuant to (G.S. 105-349) (the provisions of the municipal charter), to collect taxes on behalf of the city and any other person authorized to carry out the duties and functions of such individual. 
    Taxpayer means any person liable for the taxes imposed by this article. 
    Vehicle shall mean any of the following: 
(1)  A motor vehicle of the private passenger type, including a passenger van, minivan, or sport utility vehicle. 
(2)  A motor vehicle of the cargo type, including a cargo van, pickup truck, or truck with a gross vehicle weight of twenty-six thousand (26,000) pounds or less used predominantly in the transportation of property for other than commercial freight, and that does not require the operator to possess a commercial driver's license. 
(3)  A trailer or semi-trailer with a gross vehicle weight of six thousand (6,000) pounds or less. (G.S. 160A-215.1(e)(1)) 
(Ord. No. 00.8.2, § 1, 8-1-2000) 
Sec. 14-182. - Levy of tax. 
    A tax is hereby imposed and levied in an amount equal to one and one-half (11/2) percent of the gross receipts derived from the short-term lease or rental of vehicles at retail to the general public. This tax on gross receipts is in addition to the privilege taxes authorized by G.S. 160A-211. 
(Ord. No. 00.8.2, § 2, 8-1-2000) 
Sec. 14-183. - Collection of the tax. 
    Every person engaged in the business of the short-term lease or rental of vehicles at retail to the general public shall collect at the time of the lease or rental the tax herein levied, place the tax so collected in a segregated account, and thereafter remit such tax to the finance department in accordance with the provisions of this article. The taxpayer shall include a provision in each retail short-term lease or rental agreement stating that the percentage amount enacted by this article of the total lease or rental price, excluding sales tax, is being charged as a tax on gross receipts. The amount of the tax shall be stated separately from the lease or rental and shown separately on the taxpayer's records. The tax shall be paid by the customer to the taxpayer as trustee for and on account of the city. The taxpayer shall be liable for the collection thereof and for its payment to the finance department and the taxpayer's failure to charge or to collect said tax from the customer shall not affect such liability. 
(Ord. No. 00.8.2, § 3, 8-1-2000; Ord. No. 2008.04.01, 4-1-2008) 
Sec. 14-184. - Report and payment of tax. 
    Taxes levied under this article are due and payable when a return is required to be filed. Every taxpayer shall, within the time specified, submit a return to the finance department on the form prescribed by the finance department. A return must be signed by the taxpayer or the taxpayer's agent. Returns of taxpayers are due to the finance department each month on or before the fifteenth day of the month following the month in which the tax accrues. As provided in G.S. 160A-208.1, a return shall not be considered a public record and information contained in a return may be disclosed only in accordance therewith. 
(Ord. No. 00.8.2, § 4, 8-1-2000; Ord. No. 2008.04.02, 4-1-2008) 
Sec. 14-185. - Taxpayer to keep records. 
    The taxpayer shall keep and preserve suitable records of the gross receipts received by such taxpayer in the conduct of business and such other books or accounts as may be necessary to determine the amount of the tax for which such taxpayer is liable under the provision of this article. It shall be the duty of the taxpayer to keep and preserve for a period of three (3) years all such records of gross receipts and other books and accounts described. All records, books and accounts herein described shall be open for examination at all reasonable hours during the day by the finance department. 
(Ord. No. 00.8.2, § 5, 8-1-2000; Ord. No. 2008.04.03, 4-1-2008) 
Sec. 14-186. - Finance department to provide forms. 
    The finance department shall design, prepare, print and make available to all taxpayers operating within the municipal boundaries of the city forms and instructions for filing returns to insure a full collection of an accounting for taxes due. The failure of any taxpayer to obtain or receive forms shall not relieve such taxpayer from the payment of the tax at the time and in the manner provided. 
(Ord. No. 00.8.2, § 6, 8-1-2000; Ord. No. 2008.04.04, 4-1-2008) 
Sec. 14-187. - Situs. 
    The transaction giving rise to the tax herein levied shall be deemed to have occurred at the location of the entity from which the customer takes delivery of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 00.8.2, § 7, 8-1-2000) 
Sec. 14-188. - Penalties and remedies. 
    The provisions with respect to remedies and penalties applicable to subchapter VIII (local government sales and use tax) of chapter 105 of the General Statutes, as contained in article 5 and article 9, subchapter 1, chapter 105 thereof, shall be applicable in like manner to the tax authorized to be levied and collected under this article, to the extent that the same are not inconsistent with the provisions hereof. The governing body of the city may exercise any power to the secretary of revenue may exercise in collecting sales and use taxes. (G.S. 160A-215.1(f)) 
(Ord. No. 00.8.2, § 8, 8-1-2000) 
Sec. 14-189. - Administration. 
    In addition to the provisions herein, the levy and collection of the taxes herein imposed shall be otherwise administered in the same manner as the sales and use tax as provided in article 5, subchapter 1, chapter 105 of the General Statutes. (G.S. 160A-215.1(d)) 
(Ord. No. 00.8.2, § 9, 8-1-2000) 
ARTICLE IV. - REGISTRATION 

Secs. 14-190-14-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ITINERANT MERCHANT AND PEDDLER REGISTRATION 

Sec. 14-221. - Registration required. 
    It shall be unlawful for a transient merchant, itinerant merchant, itinerant vendor or a peddler, as defined section 14-222 (below) to engage in such business within the city without first registering with the Clinton Police Department and signing an "authority to release information" form for the purpose of the Clinton Police Department to conduct a thorough background check. The background investigation shall include a fingerprinting component. A zoning compliance statement, if applicable, will be issued by the Clinton Planning Department as the second component of the registration process. The Clinton Police Department shall issue a vendor identification badge once the background investigation and the zoning compliance statement steps have been completed. 
(Ord. No. 2015.07.02, 7-7-2015) 
Sec. 14-222. - Definition. 
    Transient merchant , itinerant merchant or peddler , for the purposes of this chapter, means any person, firm or corporation, whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, whether a resident of the city or not, who engages in a temporary business of selling and delivering goods, taking orders for future delivery, or wares and merchandise within said city, and who, in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, tent, railroad box car, or boat, public room in hotels, lodging houses, apartment, shops, or any street, alley, or other place within the city, for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares and merchandise, either privately or at public auction or travels from door-to-door for the purpose of securing orders for goods or services from on-hand inventory or for future delivery, provided that such definition shall not be construed to include: 
(1)  Any person selling edible farm products, such as fruits and vegetables under the Clinton Farmers' Market umbrella; 
(2)  Any person selling at a "flea market"; 
(3)  Any auctioneer licensed and acting under the provisions of G.S. ch. 85B; 
(4)  Any person, firm or corporation who, while occupying such temporary location, does not sell from stock, but exhibits samples only for the purpose of securing orders for future delivery only; 
(5)  Any person selling at a yard sale defined as an occasional sale (no more than four (4) times within a 12-month period) of personal property on the residential premises owned or rented for residential purposes by the seller; 
(6)  Any person, firm, or corporation who otherwise meets the definitions above but who is part of a group of ten (10) or more merchants selling at a shopping area or trade show, and is selling at the invitation of the shopping area or trade show, and where such sale activities do not last longer than seven (7) days; 
(7)  Any person selling Christmas trees and holiday decorations; 
(8)  Licensed automobile dealers selling new automobiles; 
(9)  Any church regularly established, civic organization, or regularly established brotherhoods. 
    No person, firm, or corporation so engaged shall be relieved from complying with the provisions of this chapter merely by reason of associating temporarily with any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer, or by conducting such transient business in connection with, as a part of, or in the name of any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer. 
(Ord. No. 2015.07.02, 7-7-2015) 
Sec. 14-223. - Applications. 
    The registering party shall file a written sworn registration form signed by the registering party, if an individual, by all partners if a partnership, and by the president if a corporation, with the authorized city representative, showing: 
(1)  The name or names of the person or persons having the management or supervision of applicant's business during the time that it is proposed that it will be carried on in the city; the local address or addresses of such person or persons while engaged in such business; the permanent address or addresses of such person or persons; the capacity in which such person or persons will act (that is, whether as proprietor, agent or otherwise); the name and address of the person, firm, or corporation for whose account the business will be carried on, if any; and if a corporation, under the laws of what state, the corporation is incorporated; 
(2)  Proof of a state sales tax reporting number issued by the North Carolina Department of Revenue; 
(3)  The place or places in the city where the applicant proposes to conduct business, the length of time during which it is proposed that said business shall be conducted, proof of permission from the owner or lessee of the property to be used allowing the applicant to conduct business at the proposed location; 
(4)  The place or places, other than the permanent place of business of the applicant where the applicant was conducting business within the last six (6) months; 
(5)  A statement of the nature, character and quality of the goods, wares, services or merchandise to be sold or offered for sale by the applicant, the invoice value and quality of such goods, wares, services and merchandise, whether the same are proposed to be sold from stock in possession or from stock in possession and by sample; at auction, by direct sale and by taking orders for future delivery; where the goods or property proposed to be sold are manufactured or produced and where such goods or products are located at the time said application is filed; 
(6)  A brief statement of the nature and character of the advertising done or proposed to be done in order to attract customers and copies of said advertising whether by handbills, circular, newspaper advertising, or otherwise, shall be attached to the application. Any public advertising done by an itinerant merchant must disclose the post office box number, if any, and street address, as well as city and state of the itinerant merchant's responsible place of business; 
(7)  Whether or not the person or persons having the management or supervision of the applicant's business have been convicted of a crime or the violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of such offense and the punishment assessed thereof; 
(8)  Credentials from the person, firm or corporation for which the applicant proposes to do business, authorizing the applicant to act as such representative; and 
(9)  Such other reasonable information as to the identity of character of the person or persons having the management or supervision of applicant's business as the city may deem proper to fulfill the purpose of this chapter in the protection of the public goods. 
(Ord. No. 2015.07.02, 7-7-2015) 
Sec. 14-224. - Investigation and issuance of license. 
    Upon receipt of the application, the chief of police or another authorized officer shall complete the investigation within ten (10) days. If, as a result of such investigation, the applicant's character and business responsibility are found to be unsatisfactory, the applicant shall be denied. If, as a result of the investigation, the applicant's character and business reputation appear to be satisfactory, and the Clinton Planning Department has issued its findings of zoning compliance, the police department shall so certify in writing, and an itinerant merchant badge or a peddler badge shall be issued by the police department. The police department shall keep an updated database of the issued identification badges and the database shall be fully accessible to the police officers whose duty it is to enforce compliance of this ordinance. Such database shall contain the number of the identification badge issued, the date issued, the nature of the business authorized to be carried on, the amount of processing fees paid, the expiration date of said badge, the place where said business may be carried, and the names of the persons authorized to carry on the business. 
(Ord. No. 2015.07.02, 7-7-2015) 
Sec. 14-225. - Assurity bond. 
    Before any badge shall be issued under the provisions of this article for engaging in a transient business as defined in this section, an applicant shall file with the Police department an assurity bond running to the city in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) executed by the applicant, as a principal, or a surety upon which service of process may be made in the state; said bond to be approved by the office of the city attorney, conditioned that the applicant shall comply fully with all provisions of the ordinances of the city, and the statutes of the state, regulating and concerning the sale of goods, wares, services and merchandise, and will pay all judgments rendered against said applicant for any violation of said ordinances or statutes, together with all judgments and costs that may be recovered against him by any person for damages arising out of any misrepresentation or deception practices on any person transacting such business with the applicant, whether said misrepresentations or deceptions were made or practiced by the owners or by their servants, agents, or employee, either at the time of making the sale or through any advertisement of any character whatsoever, printed or calculated with reference to the goods, wares and merchandise sold or any part thereof. Action on the bond may be brought in the name of the city to the use of the aggrieved person. The bond required by this section shall be posted and remain in effect for a period of one (1) year from the date the badge was issued, and one (1) year from the date of any renewal, of any license issued under this chapter. Such bond must be approved by the office of the city attorney, both as to form, and as to the responsibility of the surety. 
(Ord. No. 2015.07.02, 7-7-2015) 
Sec. 14-226. - Service of process. 
    Before any identification badge may be issued for any individual engaging in business as an itinerant merchant or a peddler, the applicant shall file with the police department an instrument appointing a person, firm, or corporation located in Sampson County to be the agent of applicant for service of process with respect to any matters connected with or arising out of the business transacted under the license given and the bond required by this chapter. The finance director may be named as the agent for the service of process by the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 2015.07.02, 7-7-2015) 
Sec. 14-227. - Exhibition of the identification badge. 
    The identification badge issued under this chapter shall be posted conspicuously on the person at all times. In the event that the applicant desires to have a fixed business location in more than one (1) place within the city, a separate identification badge may be issued for each person for each place of business, and shall be posted conspicuously on the person at the appropriate business location. 
(Ord. No. 2015.07.02, 7-7-2015) 
Sec. 14-228. - Display area. 
    Any itinerant merchant conducting business shall have a display area with a tent not less than ten (10) feet by ten (10) feet. No items are to be displayed on automobiles, trucks, tractors, or the ground. 
(Ord. No. 2015.07.02, 7-7-2015) 
Sec. 14-229. - Fees. 
(a)  Before issuing an identification badge under this chapter, the police department shall collect an administrative processing fee at an amount set by the city council. This fee is to cover the administrative costs of processing the application required by this chapter. It shall not be considered a tax, nor shall it relieve the applicant of paying any other state or local taxes required by law. 
(b)  The police department shall collect the administrative fee. 
(Ord. No. 2015.07.02, 7-7-2015) 
Sec. 14-230. - Identification badge not transferable. 
    The identification badge issued under this chapter shall not be transferable. 
(Ord. No. 2015.07.02, 7-7-2015) 
Sec. 14-231. - Duty of police to enforce. 
    It shall be the duty of the police officers of the city to enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2015.07.02, 7-7-2015) 
Sec. 14-232. - Revocation of an issued identification badge. 
(a)  Any identification badge revoked pursuant to this chapter may be revoked by the police department after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for license; 
(2)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in connection with the selling of goods, wares or merchandise; 
(3)  Any violation of this chapter; 
(4)  Conviction of the individual of any felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; or 
(5)  Conducting the business under this ordinance in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety and general welfare of the public. 
(b)  Notice of hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee, at his last known address, at least five (5) days prior to the date set for hearing. 
(Ord. No. 2015.07.02, 7-7-2015) 
Sec. 14-233. - Appeal. 
    Any persons aggrieved by a decision of the police department to deny or revoke an application or an issued identification badge may appeal to city manager. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the city manager, within fourteen (14) days after notice of the decision by the police department has been filed to such person's last known address, a written statement setting forth the grounds for the appeal. The city manager shall set the time and place for a hearing on such appeal and notice of such hearing shall be given to such persons in the same manner as provided in this section for notice of hearing or revocation. The order of the city manager on such appeal shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 2015.07.02, 7-7-2015) 
Sec. 14-234. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any violation of this chapter shall subject the offender to a civil penalty in the amount of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). Violators shall be issued a written citation which must be paid within seventy-two (72) hours. 
(b)  Each day's continuing violation shall be a separate and distinct offense. 
(c)  Notwithstanding subsection (a) above, provisions of this chapter may be enforced through equitable remedies issued by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(d)  In addition to or in lieu of remedies authorized in subsection (a) and (c) above, violations of this chapter may be prosecuted as a misdemeanor in accordance with G.S. 160A-175. Conviction of a misdemeanor prosecution under this chapter shall subject the offender to a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Ord. No. 2015.07.02, 7-7-2015) 
Chapter 15 - MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Vehicles restricted in parks, § 18-49; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 20; vehicles for hire, Ch. 21. 
State Law reference- Motor vehicles, G.S. Ch. 20; powers of local authorities, G.S. § 20-169; traffic control by cities generally, G.S. § 160A-300 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 15-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Alley shall mean any roadway, whether public or private, which provides for an outlet to a regular street, which is intended for vehicular travel. 
    Authorized emergency vehicle shall mean vehicles of the fire department owned by the city, cars of physicians and surgeons when answering emergency calls, and ambulances. 
    Business district shall mean the territory contiguous to a highway where seventy-five (75) percent or more of the frontage thereon for a distance of three hundred (300) feet or more is occupied by buildings in use for business purposes, or such other territory within the city designated "business district" by the chief of police and marked with signs bearing the words "business district" in letters not less than six (6) inches high, erected on the street or the edge thereof at the boundaries of such territory so designated. 
    Crosswalk shall mean: 
(1)  That portion of a roadway ordinarily included within the prolongation or extension of the lateral lines of sidewalks at intersections; 
(2)  Any portion of a roadway distinctly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface. 
    Driver shall mean every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a vehicle. 
    Intersection shall mean the area embraced within the prolongation of the lateral curblines or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of two (2) or more highways which join one another at any angle whether or not one such highway crosses the other. 
    Motor vehicle shall mean every vehicle which is self-propelled. 
    Official traffic-control devices shall mean all signs, signals, markings and devices not inconsistent with this chapter, placed or erected by authority of the police chief, for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic. 
    Official traffic signals shall mean any device, whether manually, electrically or mechanically operated, by which traffic is alternately directed to stop and go. 
    Park shall mean the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than for the temporary purpose of, and while actually engaged in, loading or unloading. 
    Pedestrian shall mean any person afoot. 
    Police chief shall mean the chief of police in the city, or the acting chief of police. 
    Police officer shall mean every officer of the city police department or any other officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic or to make arrests for violation of traffic regulations. 
    Private road or driveway shall mean every road or driveway not open to the use of the public as a matter of right for the purpose of vehicular traffic. 
    Railroad shall mean a carrier of persons or property upon cars other than streetcars, operated upon stationary rails. 
    Residential district shall mean the territory contiguous to a highway not comprising a business district, where seventy-five (75) percent or more of the frontage thereon for a distance of three hundred (300) feet or more is mainly occupied by dwellings or by dwellings and buildings in use for business purposes. 
    Right-of-way shall mean the privilege of the immediate use of the roadway. 
    Roadway shall mean that portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel. 
    Sidewalk shall mean that portion of a street between the curblines, or the lateral curblines or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of two (2) or more highways which join one another at any angle whether or not one such highway crosses the other. 
    Standing shall mean any stopping of a vehicle, whether occupied or not. 
    Stop shall mean, when required, complete cessation of movement. 
    Stop or stopping shall mean, when prohibited, any stopping of a vehicle except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the direction of a police officer or traffic-control sign or signal. 
    Street or highway shall mean the entire width between property lines of every way or place of whatever nature when any part thereof is open to the public, as a matter of right, for purposes of vehicular traffic. 
    Traffic shall mean pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles, streetcars and other conveyances either singly or together or while using the streets for purposes of travel. 
    Vehicle shall mean every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, except devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Code 1975, § 15-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 15-2. - Official traffic map. 
    An official traffic map shall be kept on file in city hall showing any of the following regulations applicable within the city: 
(1)  Location of traffic-control devices; 
(2)  Regulations applicable to parking, loading, bus stops or taxicab stands; 
(3)  Speed limits; 
(4)  Location of through streets; 
(5)  Stop intersections; 
(6)  Yield-right-of-way intersections; 
(7)  Waiting lanes; 
(8)  One-way streets; 
(9)  Truck traffic routes; 
(10)  Regulations upon vehicle turns at designated locations. 
Such map shall constitute the official codification of city ordinances or resolutions regarding those areas of traffic regulation enumerated by this section. 
(Code 1975, § 15-2) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to codify traffic regulations by use of official traffic maps, G.S. § 160A-77. 
Sec. 15-3. - Obedience to police. 
    No person shall wilfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of a police officer. 
(Code 1975, § 15-3) 
State Law reference- Obedience to traffic officers, G.S. § 20-114.1. 
Sec. 15-4. - Applicability of chapter to public employees. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the driver of any vehicle owned by, or used in the service of, the United States government, the State of North Carolina, the County of Sampson, or the City of Clinton, and it shall be unlawful for any such driver to violate any of the provisions of this chapter, except as otherwise permitted in this chapter or by general law. 
(Code 1975, § 15-5) 
Sec. 15-5. - Applicability of chapter to bicyclists, pushcarts, etc. 
    Every person propelling any pushcart or riding a bicycle or an animal upon a roadway, and every person driving any animal-drawn vehicle, shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter applicable to the driver of any vehicle, except those provisions of this chapter which by their very nature can have no application. 
(Code 1975, § 15-6) 
Cross reference- Animals, Ch. 4. 
State Law reference- Applicability of traffic laws to bicycles, G.S. § 20-38(38); applicability to persons riding animals, etc., G.S. § 20-171. 
Sec. 15-6. - Applicability of chapter to emergency vehicles. 
(a)  The provisions of this chapter regulating the operation, parking, and standing of vehicles shall apply to authorized emergency vehicles, as defined in this chapter, except as follows: A driver, when operating such a vehicle in an emergency, except when otherwise directed by a police officer, may: 
(1)  Park or stand notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter; 
(2)  Proceed past a red or a stop signal or stop sign, but only after slowing down as may be necessary for safe operation; 
(3)  Exceed the prima facie speed limits so long as he does not endanger life or property; 
(4)  Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in specified directions so long as he does not endanger life or property. 
(b)  The foregoing exemptions shall not, however, protect the driver of any such vehicle from the consequence of his reckless disregard of the safety of others. 
(Code 1975, § 15-7) 
Sec. 15-7. - Funeral processions. 
(a)  A funeral composed of a procession of vehicles shall be identified by burning lights on the cars in the procession while en route to the cemetery. 
(b)  Each driver in a funeral or other procession shall drive as near to the right-hand edge of the roadway as practical and follow the vehicle ahead as closely as practical and safe. 
(c)  No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral procession while they are in motion and when such vehicles are conspicuously designated as required in this chapter. This provision shall not apply at intersections where traffic is controlled by traffic signals or a police officer. 
(Code 1975, §§ 15-8, 15-9) 
Cross reference- Parades and demonstrations, Ch. 17. 
Sec. 15-8. - Clinging to moving vehicles. 
(a)  Any person riding upon any bicycle, motorcycle, coaster, sled, roller skates or any toy vehicle shall not attach the same or himself to any moving vehicle upon any roadway. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ride the running board, fenders or bumpers of any vehicle. 
(Code 1975, § 15-10) 
Sec. 15-9. - Use of coasters, roller skates, etc., on roadways. 
    No person upon roller skates, or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device, shall go upon any roadway except while crossing a street on a crosswalk and except on streets set aside as play streets when and as authorized by this Code or other ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 15-11) 
Sec. 15-10. - Emerging from alleys, driveways, etc. 
    The driver of a vehicle emerging from an alley, driveway or building shall stop such vehicle immediately prior to driving onto a sidewalk or into a sidewalk area across any alleyway, and shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians on the sidewalk and to all vehicles approaching on the roadway. 
(Code 1975, § 15-12) 
Sec. 15-11. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2005.3.03, adopted Mar. 1, 2005, repealed § 15-11 in its entirety. Former § 15-11 pertained to motor vehicle registration plates-generally and derived from Code 1975, § 15-13. 
Sec. 15-12. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2005.3.03, adopted Mar. 1, 2005, repealed § 15-12 in its entirety. Former § 15-12 pertained to display and derived from Code 1975, § 15-14. 
Sec. 15-12.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2005.3.03, adopted Mar. 1, 2005, repealed § 15-12.1 in its entirety. Former § 15-12.1 pertained to violations, penalties and derived from Ord. No. 87.6.1, 6-2-88. 
Sec. 15-13. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2005.3.03, adopted Mar. 1, 2005, repealed § 15-13 in its entirety. Former § 15-13 pertained to transfer and derived from Code 1975, § 15-15. 
Secs. 15-14-15-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFICIAL TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES 

Sec. 15-26. - Generally. 
(a)  The driver of any vehicle shall obey the instructions of any official traffic-control device applicable thereto, placed in accordance with this chapter, unless otherwise directed by a police officer, subject to the exceptions granted in this chapter to the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle. 
(b)  Where traffic is controlled by traffic-control signals installed as provided in this chapter, exhibiting the word "go," "caution," "stop" or exhibiting different colored lights successively, the following colors, words and lights shall indicate as follows: 
(1)  The word "go" or a green light. Vehicular traffic facing the signal may proceed straight through, or unless a sign prohibits such turn, may turn right or left. But vehicular traffic shall yield the right-of-way to other vehicles and to pedestrians lawfully within the intersection at the time such signal is exhibited. 
(2)  The word "caution" or a yellow light, when appearing immediately after or coincidentally with the green or "go" signal. Vehicular traffic facing such word or light shall stop and remain stopped until faced by a green or "go" signal illuminated alone. 
(3)  The word "stop" or a red light. Any person operating a vehicle facing the word "stop" or a red light shall bring the same to a stop before entering the nearest crosswalk or boundary of an intersection or at such other point as may be indicated by a limit line, and shall remain standing until a plain green light, or the word "go" is shown illuminated alone; provided, however, that at certain intersections in the city where signs shall have been erected by the police department indicating that a right turn is permitted on a red light, it shall not be a violation of this section for a person so operating a motor vehicle to make a right turn without stopping, but nothing in this subsection shall relieve any person operating a motor vehicle from the duty of proceeding with due caution and circumspection under the conditions then existing to avoid colliding with any pedestrian or motor vehicle lawfully using such intersection. 
(4)  Flashing signals. When a red or yellow lens is illuminated by rapid intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles shall, at least fifty (50) feet ahead of such signals, reduce speed of vehicles to not more than ten (10) miles per hour, and shall not exceed a speed of ten (10) miles per hour for a distance of fifty (50) feet after passing such signals. Where the word "stop" appears on the illuminated portion of a flashing signal, or where a stop sign is installed or erected in connection with the flashing signal, it shall be unlawful to enter the intersection or zone without coming to a full stop. 
(Code 1975, § 15-16) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to install automatic traffic-control signals, G.S. § 20-169. 
Sec. 15-27. - Obedience to turn signs and markers. 
    Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right or left or "U" turn is permitted, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of any such sign, and when authorized marks, buttons or other indications are placed within an intersection indicating the course to be travelled by vehicles turning thereat, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of such indications. 
(Code 1975, § 15-17) 
Sec. 15-28. - Quiet zones. 
    Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating a zone of quiet, no person operating a motor vehicle within any such zone shall sound the horn or other warning device of such vehicle except in an emergency. 
(Code 1975, § 15-18) 
Cross reference- Noises, § 16-5. 
Sec. 15-29. - Play streets. 
    Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating any street or part thereof as a play street, no person shall drive a vehicle upon any such street or portion thereof, except drivers of vehicles having business or whose residences are within such closed area, and then any such driver shall exercise the greatest care in driving upon any such street or portion thereof. 
(Code 1975, § 15-19) 
Sec. 15-30. - Interference with traffic-control devices and railroad signs or signals. 
    No person shall, without lawful authority, attempt to or in fact alter, deface, injure, knock down or remove any official traffic-control device or any railroad sign or signal, or any inscription, shield or insignia thereon, or any part thereof. 
(Code 1975, § 15-20) 
Sec. 15-31. - Temporary alley, parking area and street closing. 
(a)  The chief of police, or designee, is authorized to temporarily close to vehicular traffic, alleys, parking areas and streets within the city when the chief deems it necessary to meet the particular needs of a special event or project without adversely affecting vehicular traffic and not endangering public safety. 
(b)  The area and boundaries of any street closing will consist of only those areas directly related to the special event or project and shall include any public alley, parking area, street, sidewalk, or publicly owned area that is within or constitutes the boundary of that event or project. 
(c)  The police chief will notify the City of Clinton Fire Chief and Sampson County Emergency Management in advance of all closings approved. 
(Ord. No. 2007.10.03, 10-10-2007) 
Secs. 15-32-15-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012.06.01, adopted June 5, 2012, amended Art. III in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. III, §§ 15-41-15-71, pertained to the same subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks generally, Ch. 20. 
State Law reference- Stopping on a highway generally, G.S. § 20-161; municipal authority as to parking generally, G.S. § 160A-301; parking authorities, G.S. § 160A-550 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 15-41. - Owner responsible for violations. 
    No person shall allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in his name to stand or park in any street in the city in violation of any provisions of this article regulating the standing or parking of vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-42. - Obedience to parking signs. 
    When signs prohibiting parking are erected on any street no person shall park a vehicle within the area designated by such signs. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-43. - Parking signs to be erected only with city permission. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, paint on the street, or place on any street any sign, signal or device of any kind regulating or attempting to regulate the parking, stopping or control of vehicles on any street or public alley in the city, without first receiving written permission for the police chief. If such permission is given it may be withdrawn at any time, and upon such person's failure to remove the paint, sign, signal or device, the same shall be removed under direction of the police chief. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
State Law reference- Unofficial signs, G.S. § 136-32. 
Sec. 15-44. - Reserved. 
Sec. 15-45. - Servicing, repairing, etc., of parked vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to work on, repair or service in any manner any vehicle on the streets or in any alley; provided, that this shall not apply to emergency repairs necessitated in order to remove such vehicle to a garage. 
(b)  No person shall stand or park a vehicle upon any roadway for the principal purpose of washing or greasing such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-46. - Display of parked vehicles for sale. 
    No person shall stand or park a vehicle upon any roadway for the principal purpose of displaying it for sale. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-47. - Parallel parking. 
    No person shall stand or park in a roadway other than parallel with the edge of the roadway, headed in the direction of traffic, and with the curb-side wheels of the vehicle within twelve (12) inches of the edge of the roadway, except upon those streets which have been marked or signed for angle parking, in which event vehicles shall be parked at the angle to the curb indicated by such marks or signs. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-48. - Parking near hazardous or congested places. 
    When signs are erected upon an approach to hazardous or congested places, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-48.1. - Parking near fire hydrant. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to park a vehicle within seven and one-half (71/2) feet of fire hydrants in the city. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-48.2. - Parking in nondesignated areas (double parking) prohibited. 
    No person shall park or leave standing any vehicle, whether attended or unattended, other than vehicles parked diagonally at the parking places marked for diagonal parking or at parallel parking at the curb at places marked for parallel parking, but this section does not affect any parking places which are restricted as to use by office, person or loading zone or any other restriction now or hereafter adopted by this Code. Neither shall this section authorize any person to park in a parking place for a longer period of time than the time now allowed or hereafter allowed by this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-49. - Parking of commercial vehicles in residential areas. 
(a)  No commercial vehicle shall park in a residential area within the city limits except in an enclosed building; unless the city issues a permit for such parking. A permit for parking outside an enclosed building may be granted if all of the following criteria are met: 
(1)  The vehicle is not located within the front yard, street side yard, or road right-of-way of a residence as defined by the city zoning ordinance; 
(2)  The vehicle is not equipped with refrigeration equipment and can meet all standards of section 16-5; 
(3)  The street providing access to the property is not restricted to truck traffic by a sign indicating "No Trucks" or "No Thru Trucks"; 
(4)  The owner/operator has received approval from the city council after a public hearing where all owners of real property within one hundred (100) feet, including those across the street have received written notification of such request. 
(b)  A commercial vehicle is defined as follows: 
(1)  A motor vehicle that has a combined gross vehicle weight rating of at least twenty-six thousand one (26,001) pounds and includes as part of the combination a towed unit that has a gross vehicle weight rating of a least ten thousand (10,000) pounds, or 
(2)  A vehicle designed to transport sixteen (16) or more passengers, including the driver, or 
(3)  Class B: A single vehicle with a gross vehicle weight of twenty-six thousand one (26,001) pounds or more and towing a vehicle of less than ten thousand (10,000) pounds, or 
(4)  A vehicle transporting hazardous materials and is required to be placarded in accordance with 49 C.F.R. Part 172, Subpart F, or 
(5)  Any type vehicle with a refrigerated body that the refrigerated unit is operated by gasoline or diesel engine, regardless of the gross vehicle weight rating. 
(c)  Park is defined as the permitting of a vehicle to remain standing on a public highway, street, or on private property, while not in use. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-50. - On-street parking limits. 
    When signs are placed, erected, or installed in each block giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle in a parking place, not otherwise restricted by appropriate signs, for longer than two (2) consecutive hours at any time between the hours of 8:30 a.m. and 5:30 p.m. (unless other hours are designated) on any days except Saturday and Sunday, and the changing of the position of a vehicle from one (1) point to another within the same block within a period of fifteen (15) minutes shall be deemed continual parking period. Each period of time of two (2) consecutive hours a vehicle remains parking after the original two (2) hours of permitted parking shall constitute a separate offense. (See section 15-74.) 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-51. - Off-street parking zones established. 
    There are hereby established off-street parking zones, in the following zones, during the hours of 8:30 a.m. and 5:30 p.m., each day except Saturday and Sunday: 
(1)  The off-street parking lot owned by the city and located between Main Street and Sycamore Street; 
(2)  The off-street parking lot owned by the city and located on the westerly edge of Sampson Street; 
(3)  The off-street parking lot owned by the city and located between East Main Street, Connestee Street, College Street and Sampson Street, with portions of this lot leased to individuals; 
(4)  Those portions of the off-street parking lot on Lisbon Street which have been marked by signs according to appropriate resolutions of the city council; 
(5)  The off-street parking lot known as the Vance Street lot, located at the corner of Vance Street and Connestee Street. 
(Ord. No. 2012.05, 5-1-2012; Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-51.1. - Use of parking lots. 
(a)  Definitions. The term parking lot for the purposes of this section, means any area within the city on which more than five (5) automobiles may be parked and shall include public parking lots and those parking lots which are for the principal purpose of providing parking during business hours for shopping centers, stores, restaurants, drive-ins, theaters, offices, and other business or commercial establishments. 
(b)  Congregation on premises. It shall be unlawful for more than five (5) people to congregate on any one (1) parking lot in the city between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., except for the purpose of patronizing a business establishment which is actually open for business for any period between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(c)  Enumeration of offenses. It shall be unlawful for any person on a parking lot in the city between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. to do one (1) or more of the following: 
(1)  Talk in loud or boisterous manner; 
(2)  Drink beer or any kind of alcoholic beverage; 
(3)  Throw any type of bottle, can, container, trash, or paper on the parking lot; 
(4)  Use profanity or cursing in such manner that those standing in the immediate vicinity of the person may hear the profanity or cursing; 
(5)  Make such noise or disturbance that persons living in homes or other dwellings accommodations within three hundred (300) feet of the parking lot are disturbed in their place of living and deprived of their peace and quiet. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-52. - Off-street parking. 
    When signs are placed, erected, or installed in any off-street parking lot giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle in a parking place, not otherwise restricted by appropriate signs, for longer than two (2) consecutive hours at any time between the hours of 8:30 a.m. and 5:30 p.m. (unless other hours are designated) on any days except Saturday and Sunday, and the changing of the position of a vehicle from one (1) point to another within the same block within a period of fifteen (15) minutes shall be deemed continual parking period. Each period of time of two (2) consecutive hours a vehicle remains parking after the original two (2) hours of permitted parking shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-53. - Truck parking. 
    All motor truck carriers operating as either common or contract carriers over regular or irregular routes, all passenger bus carriers, and all other owners of motor trucks or trailers of any kind, including house trailers, whose trucks, truck-trailers, trailers, semi-trailers, house trailers or buses at any time are operated into, out of, through, or within the corporate limits of the city and the drivers and operators of any such vehicles shall use private property for parking and storing those vehicles within the corporate limits, and they are hereby prohibited from using the public streets of the city except for the purposes of travel and transporting, loading and unloading passengers and except for temporary parking in cases of emergency involving a mechanical breakdown necessitating repairs to any such vehicle. The provisions of this section shall not apply to trucks of three-fourths-ton capacity or less, nor shall it apply to school buses parked in conformity with permits issued by the police department. 
(Ord. No. 2017.07.02, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 15-54. - Angular parking. 
    Any vehicle parked in any parking space laid out at an angle to the curb shall be parked with the front of such vehicle facing the curb and the front wheels shall be within twelve (12) inches of the curb and headed in the direction of traffic. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-55. - Parking spaces marked. 
    The chief of police, or such officers or persons as he may select, shall place lines or marks on the curb or on the street or off-street parking lots to designate the parking spaces. No vehicle shall be parked across any such line or mark, or in any such way that the same shall not be within the area so designated by such line or markings; and all vehicles must be parked headed in the direction of traffic. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-56. - Reserved. 
Sec. 15-57. - Defacing time indicators. 
    No unauthorized person shall alter, deface, remove, destroy, interfere or tamper with any parking regulatory time indicators, including, but not limited to, chalk markings. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-58. - Unauthorized parking in leased spaces. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to or in any manner occupy or block any parking space leased by the city to any individual, on any parking lot owned by the city without assigned written authorization by the lessee of the parking space involved. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-59. - Parking for law enforcement officers. 
    (a) Parking spaces for law enforcement officers shall be designated by signs from time to time by the city council. 
(b)  Punishment for violation of this section shall be the same as that provided in subsection 15-58(b). Any member of the city police department, with the approval of his immediate superior officer on duty, is hereby authorized to remove or cause to be removed any vehicle or other physical object parked in or blocking any of such parking spaces in violation of this section to the garage designated by the police department, and the vehicle or physical object shall be held until claimed by the legal owner or otherwise disposed of as provided by law. Any person moving and storing such motor vehicle or physical object as authorized by this section shall be deemed to be the agent of the owner of such vehicle or physical object for the purpose of the cost for removal and storage being a lien upon such vehicle or physical object. The cost of such removal and storage shall be borne by the owner of such vehicle or physical object. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-60. - Reserved. 
Sec. 15-61. - Penalty for violations. 
    Violators of the provisions of sections 15-47 through 15-48.2, 15-50, 15-55, 15-58 and 15-59 shall be punished by the violator paying a civil penalty of ten dollars ($10.00) for each violation to the city police department; violators of the provisions of section 15-51 shall be punished by the violator paying a civil penalty of five dollars ($5.00) for each violation to the city police department. The city police department shall conspicuously attach to such vehicle a notice or ticket in such form, as the chief of police may determine. Such penalty shall be due and payable within five (5) days of the dating of such citation and shall be paid such penalty at city hall. Failure to pay the penalty within the period aforesaid shall be punishable as provided in section 1-10 of this Code. Any member of the city police department is authorized, in his discretion, to have any vehicle parked in violation of this article towed at the owner's expense. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Secs. 15-62-15-64. - Reserved. 
Sec. 15-65. - Handicapped parking. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful: 
(1)  To park or leave standing any vehicle in a space designated with a sign pursuant to subsection (d) of this section for handicapped persons or visually impaired persons when the vehicle does not display the distinguishing license plate, placard, or identification card as provided in this section or disabled veteran registration plate issued pursuant to G.S. 20-81.4; 
(2)  For any reason not qualifying for the rights and privileges extended to handicapped or visually impaired persons under this section to exercise or attempt to exercise such rights or privileges by the unauthorized use of a distinguishing license plate, placard, or identification card issued pursuant to the provisions of this section; 
(3)  To park or leave standing any vehicle so as to obstruct a curb ramp or curb cut for handicapped persons as provided for by the state building code or as designated in G.S. 136-44.14; 
(4)  For those responsible for designating parking spaces for the handicapped to erect or otherwise use signs not conforming to G.S. 270-37.6(d) for this purpose. 
(b)  This section is enforceable in all public vehicular areas specified in G.S. 20-4.01(32). 
(c)  A violation of G.S. 20-37.6(e)(1), (2) or (3) is an infraction which carries a penalty of at least fifty dollars ($50.00) but not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and whenever evidence shall be presented in any court of the fact that any automobile, truck, or other vehicle was found to be parked in a properly designated handicapped parking space in violation of the provisions of this section, it shall be prima facie evidence in any court in the state that the vehicle was parked and left in the space by the person in whose name the vehicle is registered and licensed according to the records of the Division of Motor Vehicles. No evidence tendered or presented under this authority shall be admissible or competent in any respect in any court or tribunal except in cases concerned solely with a violation of this section. 
(d)  A violation of G.S. 20-37.6(e)(4) is an infraction which carries a penalty of at least fifty dollars ($50.00) but not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and whenever evidence shall be presented in any court of the fact that any such nonconforming sign or markings are being used it shall be prima facie evidence in any court in the state that the person with ownership of the property where said nonconforming sign or markings are located is responsible for violation of this section. Building inspectors and others responsible for the state building code violations specified in G.S. 143-138(h) where such signs are required by the handicapped section of the state building code, may cause a citation to be issued for this violation and may initiate any appropriate action or proceeding to correct such violation. 
(e)  A law enforcement officer, including a security officer who has authority to enforce laws on the property of his employer as specified in G.S. 74A, may cause a parked vehicle in violation of this section to be towed; and such officer shall be the legal processor as provided in G.S. 20-161(d)(2). This law enforcement officer, or security officer, shall not be held to answer in any civil or criminal action to any owner, lien holder, or other person legally entitled to the possession of any motor vehicle, is willfully, maliciously, or negligently damaged in the removal from aforesaid space to place or storage. 
(f)  Notwithstanding any other provision of the General Statutes, the provisions of this section relative to handicapped parking shall be enforced by state, county, city and other municipal authorities in their respective jurisdictions whether on public or private property in the same manner as is used to enforce other parking laws and ordinances by such agencies. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-66. - Fire lanes. 
(a)  Parking or obstruction prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to park and leave unattended a motor vehicle or to put or place any other object, structure or obstruction in a fire lane which has been properly established and marked. 
(b)  Establishment; marking. 
(1)  The fire chief is hereby authorized to establish and designate fire lanes on privately owned "public vehicular areas", as that term is defined in G.S. 20-4.01(32) for the protection and safety of lives and property. 
(2)  Fire lanes may be designated on any public vehicular area when the fire chief determines that parking or placing of vehicles or other obstructions in that area would interfere with the proper ingress of fire and other emergency vehicles, equipment, or personnel. 
(3)  Fire lanes shall be clearly marked, in yellow or other suitable color of paint, with the words "NO PARKING FIRE LANE", and the boundaries, borders or curbs shall be clearly visible and definable. 
(4)  Where the fire chief establishes and designates fire lanes, the fire chief shall notify the owner of the property by certified mail, return receipt requested, and the owner shall, within thirty (30) days of notification, mark the fire lanes as directed by the fire chief. 
(c)  Towing of unlawfully parked vehicles. In addition to the penalty provisions described in section 15-71, any vehicle unlawfully parked in a properly designated and marked fire lane may be removed or towed to a storage garage at the vehicle owner's expense. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Secs. 15-67-15-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REMOVAL OF ILLEGALLY PARKED VEHICLES 

Sec. 15-71. - Charges to constitute lien. 
(a)  Generally. All towing, storage, advertising and other charges incurred by the city or imposed upon the owner or operator of the vehicle in connection with the impounded vehicle shall constitute a lien upon such vehicle, and no such impounded vehicle shall be released until all charges have been paid to the city. 
(b)  Notification of owner. It shall be the duty of the police chief to notify the owner of such vehicle in writing, by registered mail, return receipt requested, within seventy-two (72) hours, of the fact that such vehicle has been impounded, setting forth the reason for such impounding and the amount of the charges constituting a lien thereon. If such vehicle is registered in this or any other state, the registered owner thereof, as shown by the records of the state of its registration, shall be deemed to be the owner of the vehicle, and the mailing of the notice required to such registered owner at the address shown on such records shall be deemed sufficient notification hereunder. 
(c)  Enforcement. If the owner of any vehicle impounded hereunder shall fail to pay the charges constituting a lien against such vehicle and claim such vehicle within thirty (30) days after notice has been mailed as required by subsection (b) above, action shall be instituted for the amount of such lien and the lien shall be enforced and the vehicle shall be disposed of as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-72. - Enforcement of article. 
    It shall be the duty of the police department, by and through designated officers, to civilly enforce the provisions of this article. Nothing herein shall deprive the city of its remedies to enforce violations of this article by towing, by legally permissible immobilization of the motor vehicle, or by any other civil remedies otherwise available. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-73. - Civil penalties for violations of parking ordinance. 
(a)  In addition to the other sanctions provided in this article for violation of these provisions, any violation of this article shall also subject the offender to those civil penalties hereinafter enumerated. Such civil penalties may be recovered by the city in a civil action in the nature of debt or may be collected in such other amounts as prescribed herein within the prescribed time following the issuance of notice or citation for such violation. 
(b)  Whenever a member of the police department of the city or other person charged by ordinance or charter with the enforcement of the provisions of this article regulating the parking of vehicles shall find that any of such provisions are being, or have been, violated by the owner or operator of any vehicle, such officer or person shall notify such owner or operator of such vehicle of such violation by conspicuously attaching to such vehicle a parking violation notice or citation in such form as the chief of police may direct (or by personal service of such notice or citation if the vehicle has been moved since the violation occurred). 
(c)  Such parking violation notice or citation shall among other things: 
(1)  State upon its face the amount of the civil penalties for the specific violation if such penalty be paid within five (5) days from and after such violation and the additional civil penalties if paid more than seven (7) days after its issuance. 
(2)  Notify such offender that a failure to pay the penalties within the prescribed time may subject such offender to a civil action in the nature of debt for the stated penalty (or penalties) plus an additional civil penalty in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00), together with the cost of the action to be taxed by the court. 
(3)  Provide that such offender may respond to the city parking citation by mailing or by delivering such citation and stated penalty to the Finance Department, P.O. Box 199, Clinton, North Carolina 28329, and that upon prompt and proper payment, such claim and right of action by the city will be deemed compromised and settled. 
(4)  State that such penalties must be either paid or such failure to pay must be cleared with the finance department within seven (7) days of the issuance of such citation. 
(5)  State that if such parking violation citation is not cleared within seven (7) days, court action by the filing of a civil complaint for collection of such penalty may be taken. As used upon such parking violation citation, the word "cleared" shall mean either: 
a.  Payment; 
b.  Mutually satisfactory arrangement for payment to be made; or 
c.  A prima facie showing that such parking citation was received as a result of mistake, inadvertence or excusable neglect. 
(d)  The finance department of the city is authorized to accept such payments in full and final settlement of the claim or right of action which the city may have to enforce such penalty by civil action in the nature of debt. Acceptance of such penalty (when properly and promptly paid) shall be deemed a full and final release of any and all such claims, or right of action arising out of such violation. 
(e)  The following civil penalties shall be imposed for violations in those cases in which payment is made within the prescribed forty-eight-hour period: 
(1)  Any violation involving parking in a space properly designed by the R7-8 or R7-8a sign, as described in the federal and/or state Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices, for physically handicapped persons (whether on public or private property) when the vehicle does not display the distinguishing license plate or placard, or in front of any handicap access ramp ..... $50.00 
(2)  Any violation involving parking in any legally designated fire lane (whether on public or private property) ..... 25.00 
(3)  For violations of this article involving unauthorized parking, standing or stopping within a taxicab stand, hydrant zone, loading zone, traffic lane or other prohibited zone, or in front of a driveway, or on the left-hand side of a two-way street in a business district, or on a sidewalk or sidewalk area, or for double parking, or for any other prohibited purpose ..... 10.00 
(4)  Overtime parking and other violations not otherwise specified in this article ..... 10.00 
(f)  In addition to the civil penalties prescribed in subsection (e) above, an additional ten dollar ($10.00) civil penalty shall be imposed in all those cases in which the above penalties have not been paid within the authorized seven-day period. Should it become necessary to institute a civil action to collect any fees or penalties hereunder, then the violation shall also be subject to an additional civil penalty of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec 15-74. - Presumption of violation. 
    The registered owner of a vehicle found in violation of this article shall be held prima facie responsible for any such violation. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-75. - Continuous violations. 
    Each hour's continuing violation shall constitute a separate and distinct offense, and the civil penalties imposed hereunder shall be cumulative. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-76. - Use of civil penalties. 
    The civil penalties collected under this article shall be delivered daily to the city finance director who shall count the money and deposit the same to the credit of the parking fund. The fund shall be disbursed only by the city council; and the money derived therefrom shall be used only for the costs of collecting the civil penalties (including personnel, overhead, supplies, equipment, postage and related expenses to the extent that they are attributable to administering and collecting the penalties). Any excess amount collected shall be used only for the maintenance or improvements of the parking facilities and streets. This section shall be deemed complied with if any amount equal to the amount deposited in the general fund of the city from the proceeds of the parking fund is spent on the purposes provided during the year in which the transfer is made. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 15-77. - Affidavit prima facie evidence of parking citations. 
    In the enforcement of any parking violations under this article (including overtime parking, standing or stopping within a traffic lane, hydrant zone, loading zone, handicapped parking zone, fire lane or other prohibited zone, in front of a driveway, on the left-hand side of a two-way street in a business district, or on a sidewalk or sidewalk area, or for double parking, or for any prohibited purpose), an affidavit signed by the chief of police (or any other officer with the police department who is in charge of keeping the records relating thereto) certifying that the records are kept under the custody of the affiant and further certifying that parking citations, notices or tickets listed on or attached to the affidavit are citations which the police records and procedures indicate were placed on a motor vehicle registered at the time in the name of the defendant and/or certifying any payments made by reason of said citations, notices or tickets and the balance owing thereon according to the police records, shall be prima facie evidence of the facts contained in the affidavit and shall further be admissible as prima facie evidence that the defendant is responsible for the payment of the parking citations, notices or tickets set forth in the affidavit. 
    There shall further be a prima facie presumption that the parking citation, notice or ticket was placed upon the motor vehicle on each occasion set forth in the affidavit and that said parking citation, notice or ticket was on the form of the standard parking citation or ticket used by the City of Clinton Police Department at said respective time and was properly completed. It shall not be necessary for the ticketing policeman to appear or testify in corroboration of any facts set forth in said affidavit or of the matters set forth in this section. 
(Ord. No. 2012.06.01, 6-5-2012) 
Secs. 15-78-15-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - REMOVAL AND DISPOSITION OF ABANDONED AND NUISANCE MOTOR VEHICLES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Art. IV, Removal of abandoned or junked vehicles, derived from Code 1975, §§ 15-36-15-45, was repealed in its entirety. Ord. No. 90.4.2 adopted a new Art. IV, Removal and disposition of abandoned and nuisance motor vehicles, §§ 15-86-15-99. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to dispose of junked or abandoned motor vehicles, G.S. § 160A-303. 

Sec. 15-86. - Administration. 
    The police department and the code enforcement officer of the city shall be responsible for administering the removal and disposition of vehicles determined to be "abandoned" on the public streets and highways within the city, of abandoned and nuisance vehicles on private property, and on any other property owned or operated by the city. The city may, on an annual basis, contract with private tow truck operators or vehicles in compliance with this article and applicable state laws. Nothing in this article shall be construed to limit the legal authority or powers of officers of the city police department and fire department in enforcing other laws or ordinances, or in otherwise carrying out their duties. 
(Ord. No. 90.4.2, 4-3-90; Ord. No. 2013.03.08, 3-5-2013) 
Sec. 15-87. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Abandoned vehicle means a vehicle that is: 
(a)  Left upon a public street or highway in violation of a law or ordinance prohibiting parking; or 
(b)  Left on a public street or highway for longer than seven (7) days; or 
(c)  Left on property owned or operated by the city for longer than twenty-four (24) hours; or 
(d)  Left on private property without the consent of the owner, occupant, or lessee thereof, for longer than two (2) hours. 
    Authorizing official means the supervisory employee of the police department or the code enforcement officer, respectively, designated to authorize the removal of vehicles under the provisions of this article. 
    Motor vehicle or vehicle means a machine designed or intended to travel over land by self propulsion or while attached to any self-propelled vehicle. 
    Nuisance vehicle means a motor vehicle on public or private property that is determined and declared to be a health or safety hazard, a public nuisance, including found to be: 
(a)  A breeding ground or harbor for mosquitoes or other insects or a breeding ground or harbor for rats or other pests; 
(b)  A point of heavy growth of weeds or other noxious vegetation over eight (8) inches in height; 
(c)  A point of collection of pools or ponds of water; 
(d)  A point of concentration of combustible items such as gasoline, oil, or other flammable or explosive materials, including, but not limited to boxes, paper, old clothes, rags, refuse or any other combustible materials or objects of a like nature; 
(e)  One which has parts, thereof, which may fail and injure members of the public or one which may have parts which may fall or be closed and become an area of confinement form which release may not be had by opening from the inside; 
(f)  One which is so situated and located that there is danger of the vehicle falling, rolling, turning over, or creating an unsafe movement, such as unattended, blocked or jacked vehicles; 
(g)  One which is a point of collection of garbage, food waste, or any other rotten or putrescible matter of any kind; 
(h)  One which has parts thereof which are jagged or contain sharp edges of metal, glass or other hard material; 
(i)  Any other vehicle specifically declared a health and safety hazard and public nuisance by the city council; 
(j)  One which cannot be self-propelled or moved in the manner in which it was originally intended to move; or 
(k)  One which does not display a current license plate. 
(Ord. No. 90.4.2, 4-3-90; Ord. No. 2006.02.3, 2-7-2006) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.S. § 160A-303(b). 
Sec. 15-88. - Abandoned vehicle unlawful; removal authorized. 
    It shall be unlawful for the registered owner or any other person in possession thereof, whether, lawfully or not, to cause or allow such vehicle to be abandoned as the term is defined herein. 
    Upon investigation, proper officials of the city may determine that a vehicle is an abandoned vehicle and order the vehicle removed. 
(Ord. No. 90.4.2, 4-3-90) 
Sec. 15-89. - Nuisance vehicle unlawful; removal authorized. 
    It shall be unlawful for the registered owner or any other person in possession thereof, whether lawfully or not, or for the owner, lessee or occupant of the real property upon which the vehicle is located to leave or allow the vehicle to remain on the property after it has been declared a nuisance vehicle. 
    Upon investigation, proper officials of the office of the code enforcement officer's office may determine and declare that a vehicle is a health or safety hazard and a nuisance vehicle as defined above, and order the vehicle removed. 
(Ord. No. 90.4.2, 4-3-90) 
Sec. 15-90. - Removal of abandoned or nuisance vehicles; pre-towing notice requirements. 
    Except as set forth in section 15-91, a vehicle to be removed because it has been abandoned or declared to be a nuisance vehicle shall be towed only after a notice to the registered owner or person entitled to possession of the vehicle. In such instances notice shall be given by affixing on the windshield or some other conspicuous place on the vehicle a notice indicating that the vehicle will be removed by the city on a specified date (no sooner than seven days after notice is affixed), unless the vehicle is moved by the owner or legal possessor prior to this time. Except that when the vehicle is located upon private property, in lieu of affixing notice on the windshield or some other conspicuous place on the vehicle, said notice may be given by mailing it by certified mail to the owner or occupant of the property upon which the vehicle is located at the address shown at the Sampson County Tax Office, Office of the City of Clinton Water Department, or the Sampson County Emergency Management Administration Office, at least ten (10) days prior to the removal of said vehicle. 
    With respect to abandoned vehicles and nuisance vehicles, if the registered owner or person entitled to possession does not remove the vehicle but chooses to appeal the determination that the vehicle is abandoned or a nuisance vehicle, such appeal shall be made to the city council in writing, heard at a regularly scheduled meeting of the council, and further proceedings to remove the vehicle shall be stayed until the appeal is heard and decided. 
(Ord. No. 90.4.2, 4-3-90; Ord. No. 97.4.2, 4-1-97) 
Sec. 15-91. - Exceptions to prior notice requirements. 
    The requirement that notice be affixed to an abandoned or nuisance vehicle at least seven days prior to removal may, as determined by the authorizing official, be omitted in those circumstances where there is a special need for prompt action to eliminate traffic obstruction or to otherwise maintain and protect the public safety and welfare. Such findings shall, in all cases, be entered by the authorizing official in the appropriate daily records. Circumstances without prior notice include: 
(1)  Vehicles abandoned on the streets or highways. For vehicles left on the public streets and highways, such circumstances include, and the city council hereby determines that immediate removal of such vehicles may be warranted when they are: 
a.  Obstructing traffic; 
b.  Parked in a no-stopping or standing zone; 
c.  Parked in loading zones; 
d.  Parked in violation of temporary parking restrictions imposed by the city code. 
(2)  Other abandoned or nuisance vehicles. With respect to abandoned or nuisance vehicles left on property owned or operated by the city other than the streets and highways, and on private property, such vehicles may be removed without giving prior notice only in those circumstances where the authorizing official finds a special need for prompt action to protect and maintain the public health, safety and welfare. By way of illustration, but not limitation, such circumstances include vehicles blocking or obstructing ingress or egress to businesses and residences, vehicles parked in such a location or manner as to pose a traffic hazard, and vehicles causing damage to private property. 
(Ord. No. 90.4.2, 4-3-90) 
Sec. 15-92. - Removal of vehicles; post-towing notice requirements. 
    Any vehicle which has been determined to be an abandoned vehicle or a nuisance vehicle may, as directed by the city, be removed to a storage garage area by the tow-truck operator, towing business contracting to perform such services for the city, or by a city vehicle. Whenever such a vehicle is removed, the authorizing city official shall immediately notify the last known registered owner of the vehicle, such notice to include the following: 
(1)  Description of the removed vehicle; 
(2)  The location where the vehicle is stored; 
(3)  The violation with which the owner or person legally entitled to possession must follow to redeem the vehicle; and 
(4)  The procedure the owner or person legally entitled to possession must follow to redeem the vehicle; and 
(5)  The procedure the owner or person legally entitled to possession must follow to request a probable cause hearing on the removal. 
    The city shall attempt to give notice to the vehicles owner and person legally entitled to possession (if known); however, whether or not the owner and/or person legally entitled to possession is reached by telephone, written notice, including the information set forth in sub-section (a) through (e) of this section, shall, unless this notice is waived in writing by the vehicle owner or agent, also must be mailed to the owner's last known address. 
    If the vehicle is registered in North Carolina, notice shall be given within twenty-four hours. If the vehicle is not registered in North Carolina, notice shall be given to the registered within seventy-two hours from the removal of the vehicle. 
    Whenever an abandoned or nuisance vehicle is removed, and such vehicle has valid registration plate, the authorizing city official shall make reasonable efforts, including checking the vehicle identification number, to determine the last known address and identity of the last known registered owner of the vehicle, and to notify him of the information as set forth in subsections (a) through (e) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 90.4.2, 4-3-90) 
Sec. 15-93. - Right to probable cause hearing before sale or final disposition of vehicle. 
    After the removal of an abandoned or nuisance vehicle, the owner or any other person legally entitled to possession of the vehicle is entitled to a hearing for the purpose of determining if probable cause existed for removing the vehicle. A request for hearing must be filed in writing with a Sampson county magistrate designated by the chief judge of the Fourth Judicial District to receive such hearing requests. The magistrate will set the hearing in seventy-two (72) hours of receipt of the request, and the hearing will be conducted in accordance with the provisions of § 20-222 of the general statutes, and as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 90.4.2, 4-3-90) 
Sec. 15-94. - Redemption of vehicle during proceedings.
