(Code 1975, § 18-12; Ord. No. 94.1.4, 11-1-94; Amend. of 10-6-98; Ord. No. 2005.12.05, 12-6-2005; Ord. No. 2016.10.03, 10-4-2016) 
Sec. 18-18. - Same-Repeated failure to attend without cause. 
    A failure of any member of the recreation advisory committee to attend three (3) consecutive regular meetings of the committee without leave of the committee, except when such absences are made necessary by sickness or other similar emergency causes, will operate to forfeit and declare vacant the seat of such member on the committee. 
(Code 1975, § 18-13) 
Sec. 18-19. - Powers and duties. 
    The powers and duties of the recreation advisory committee shall be to: 
(1)  Select from its membership its chairman and such other officers as considered necessary and to adopt bylaws under which it will operate; 
(2)  Plan and recommend by regular and special reports to the city council such action as may be necessary to create and develop an adequate and complete system of parks, playgrounds and recreation centers and facilities; 
(3)  Advise the city manager concerning the supervision, organization and management of parks and playgrounds and activities thereon, of recreation and social centers, play fields, natatoriums, and similar facilities, in order that the best and most satisfactory provision for supervision of community sports of all kinds, community singing, music, games, plays, celebrations and similar activities will be properly developed; 
(4)  Cooperate with individuals, firms or organizations interested in public recreation; 
(5)  Recommend such clean and wholesome recreation and amusement for the citizens of the city as it shall deem advisable; 
(6)  Cooperate with any public authority and to aid and assist in coordinating recreational activities, pursuant to and in accord with chapter 160A, article 8, of the general statutes as amended, and with the provisions of this chapter; 
(7)  Carry out the directions of the city council and the city manager, and, subject to the directions of the city council or the city manager, to make all recommendations to the director of recreation in organizing and directing the use of all playgrounds and recreational centers owned, operated or maintained by the city. 
(Code 1975, § 18-14) 
Sec. 18-20. - Annual report. 
    The recreation advisory committee shall render annually to the city council a full report of its work. 
(Code 1975, § 18-15) 
Sec. 18-21. - Incurring financial liability. 
    Neither the recreation advisory committee nor any person representing the committee shall incur any financial liability in the name of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 18-16) 
Secs. 18-22-18-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DEPARTMENT OF RECREATION 

Sec. 18-31. - Established. 
    There is hereby created the department of recreation and the office of the director of recreation to be subject to the general control and supervision of the city manager. 
(Code 1975, § 18-17) 
Sec. 18-32. - Director of recreation-Appointment; term; compensation. 
    The director of recreation shall be appointed by the city manager to serve until his successor has been appointed and qualified. He shall be paid such compensation as may be fixed by the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 18-18) 
Sec. 18-33. - Same-Powers and duties. 
(a)  The director of recreation shall have general supervision, direction and control, under the direction of the city manager, over the recreation department, and over all matters pertaining to public recreation, including public playgrounds, public parks and other public property, used or intended for public recreational purposes in the city. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the director to supervise generally, administer and control the use of all of the public playgrounds, public parks and equipment owned by the city within the city and used or intended for use for public recreation. The director shall have the duty and authority to promulgate reasonable rules and regulations not inconsistent with this Code or any other ordinance adopted by the city council, for the proper and efficient administration of the department of recreation and for the wholesome use of such recreational facilities and equipment by the general public to the end that the greatest benefit from the use of such facilities shall be gained by the citizens of the city. 
(c)  For the purpose of properly and efficiently carrying out the provisions of this chapter, the director shall have authority to employ and to discharge, within the limits of the budget and with the approval of the city manager, all playleaders, playground directors, supervisors, recreation specialists, maintenance personnel, and such other employees as the director may deem necessary and proper. 
(d)  The director shall enforce all the provisions of this Code and of other ordinances of the city regulating playgrounds and recreation centers and their use and shall, in furtherance of such duty, have the power to remove or cause to be removed and excluded from any of the playgrounds, amusement facilities, and recreation centers, any person violating any such ordinances, or any rules or regulations concerning the use of such facilities, for a period of not to exceed twenty-four (24) hours. He shall have the care and control of all equipment, grounds and paraphernalia owned or controlled by the city for use for playgrounds or recreation purposes, and shall be responsible for the custody of such property. 
(Code 1975, § 18-19) 
Sec. 18-34. - Funding and expenditures. 
    The city council may, at its discretion, appropriate such moneys as it may deem necessary for the purpose of carrying on the activities of the recreation department. The recreation advisory committee shall act in an advisory capacity to the recreation director and the city manager in developing the annual budgetary request to be presented for consideration by the city council. Funds received by the committee or the recreation department other than revenue from appropriations and facilities of the recreation department shall be used to supplement the department's budget. Such funds shall be paid to the city, shall be disbursed for the purposes for which the funds were accepted in the same manner as other department funds. 
(Code 1975, § 18-20) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to fund parks and recreation system, G.S. § 160A-356. 
Sec. 18-35. - Recreation department officials. 
    The recreation department shall have the authority to designate its advisory board members as recreation department officials for the purpose of informing citizens about this chapter and supervising facilities in accordance with this chapter as requested by the recreation director. 
(Code 1975, § 18-22) 
Secs. 18-36-18-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - RECREATION FACILITIES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-46. - Activities sponsored by department. 
    Activities sponsored by the recreation department shall have priority in using recreation facilities. Other usage shall be on a first-come, first-served basis. 
(Code 1975, § 18-37(f)) 
Sec. 18-47. - Supervision of users. 
    All picnic parties, all groups, and all business entertainments permitted shall occupy grounds and rooms or buildings to be designated by the director and shall be under his supervision and control. 
(Code 1975, § 18-37(g)) 
Sec. 18-48. - Hours of operation. 
    All recreation areas shall be open to be public between sunrise and sunset or as posted on each day and it shall be unlawful for any person to use or inhabit any recreation area at any time except when the recreation area is being operated under the direct supervision of the recreation department, when it is being used by written authorization of the recreation department or its designated official, or when it is being used for the purpose for which it is designated, under lighting provided by the recreation department, for that purpose. 
(Code 1975, § 18-21; Ord. No. 2006.02.04, 2-7-2006) 
Sec. 18-49. - Vehicles in parks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or propel any motor vehicle, minibike, motorcycle or other vehicle in, over or through any recreation area. It shall be unlawful for any person to park or permit to be parked any vehicle anywhere except upon designated parking areas authorized by the recreation department or its designated official. 
(Code 1975, § 18-23) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 15. 
Sec. 18-50. - Destruction of property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to remove, destroy, mutilate or deface any structure, monument, statue, planter, fountain, wall, fence, railing, vehicle, bench, picnic table, tree, plants, or any other property in any recreation area or recreation center. 
(Code 1975, § 18-24) 
Sec. 18-51. - Disorderly conduct. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use any profane, boisterous or insulting language or to be guilty of disorderly conduct of any kind in any recreation area. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make or cause to be made any loud, disturbing or unnecessary noises in any recreation area except normal cheering and applauding during the progress of a duly authorized activity. 
(Code 1975, § 18-29) 
Sec. 18-52. - Firearms. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, except duly authorized recreation department employees, officials, or law enforcement officers in the course of their duties, to discharge, shoot, fire or explode any firearm, or any air rifle, toy pistol, toy gun, or other toy designed to forcibly hurl a projectile or missile, at any time and under any circumstances within any recreation area, or to carry any firearms or dangerous weapons in any recreation area. Archery equipment, slingshots or other similar devices shall be shot or discharged only in those areas within the recreation department specifically set aside for such purposes and so posted. 
(Code 1975, § 18-25) 
Cross reference- Discharging firearms in the city, § 16-3. 
Sec. 18-53. - Alcoholic beverages and narcotic drugs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to bring upon, possess, consume or display any beer, wine, malt or alcoholic beverage containing more than one (1) percent of alcohol or any narcotic drugs in any recreation area; and it shall be unlawful for any person under the influence of the above listed beverages or any narcotic drugs to enter or remain within any recreation area. 
(Code 1975, § 18-30) 
Sec. 18-54. - Molesting animals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to trap, catch, wound or kill or cause to be injured, treat cruelly, or tease, or attempt to trap, catch, wound, kill, injure or tease any bird or animal or molest or rob any nest of any bird, or any lair, den or burrow of any animal in or upon any recreation area owned by the city and administered by the recreation department or its designated officials. 
(Code 1975, § 18-36) 
Cross reference- Animals, Ch. 4. 
Sec. 18-55. - Gambling. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or carry on any game of chance in any recreation area or recreation center at which any money, property, or other thing of value is bet, whether the same be in the stake or not. 
(Code 1975, § 18-28) 
Sec. 18-56. - Leaving refuse in recreation areas. 
    Except in containers provided for that purpose, no person shall leave, deposit, dump, throw, cast, lay or place, or cause to be deposited, dumped, thrown, cast, laid, or placed any ashes, trash, rubbish, soil, earth, paper, garbage, refuse, debris, plant clippings or limbs or leaves in or upon any recreation areas or in any watercourse, lake, pond or slough within any recreation areas. Dumpsters placed on recreation and park areas shall be used for park refuse only. It shall be unlawful for private citizens or businesses to use park dumpsters for their private refuse. 
(Code 1975, § 18-31) 
Cross reference- Garbage and trash, Ch. 11. 
Sec. 18-57. - Fires. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make a fire in any recreation area except in a regularly constructed fireplace or grill. It shall be unlawful for any person to leave any fire unattended or to fail to completely extinguish a fire and all embers thereof before leaving the fire. 
(Code 1975, § 18-32) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 9. 
Sec. 18-58. - Excavating and metal detecting on city property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make an excavation in any recreation area for any purpose without written permission from the recreation department or its designated official. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to possess or use a metal detector or probe to search for objects in, on or below the surface of the soil or make an excavation in any park or recreation area for any purpose except in the following situations: 
(1)  When using the metal detector or doing excavation while under contract by the city for purposes related to the completion of work as approved by the city. 
(2)  Permission may be granted by the recreation department or its designated official for a metal detector to be used at a specifically identified park or recreation area to locate and recover a specific item of personal property which has been lost by the person requesting such permission. 
    This section does not apply to activities conducted by city employees during the course of their duties for the city. 
(Code 1975, § 18-33; Ord. No. 2009.06.01, 6-2-2009) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2009.06.01, adopted June 2, 2009, amended § 18-58 title to read as herein set out. Former § 18-58 title pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Cross reference- Excavations in streets generally, § 20-16. 
Sec. 18-59. - Games; sports. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to play football, golf, baseball, or other games of like character in any recreation area except in specifically designated areas. At no time and under no circumstances shall such games be played in such proximity to playground equipment or recreation area structures as to threaten bodily harm to persons using the recreation area or damage to recreation area structures. 
(Code 1975, § 18-34) 
Sec. 18-59.1. - Skateboarding safety equipment requirements. 
(a)  Purpose. G.S. 99E limits the liability of municipalities for damages that might arise out of a person's participation in skateboarding when the municipality adopts an ordinance requiring any person riding a skateboard in areas designated for that purpose to wear certain protective gear. Although the city is not designating any area of Royal Lane Park, other than the existing skate park facility, as a skateboarding area, the city desires to adopt an ordinance requiring any person riding a skateboard on any approach to the skate park facility in Royal Lane Park to wear protective gear. 
(b)  Protective gear requirements. Every person operating a skateboard within Royal Lane Park shall wear a protective helmet with the chin strap securely fastened under the chin, protective elbow pads and kneepads. 
(c)  Enforcement. Violations of this article shall be deemed infractions pursuant to G.S. 14-4 punishable by a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) and any other costs as prescribed by law. 
(d)  Parent/guardian responsibility. No parent or guardian of any juvenile operating a skateboard described in subsection (a) above shall knowingly allow a violation of this section. The parents or guardians of juveniles fifteen (15) years of age or under shall be deemed responsible for ensuring such compliance. 
(e)  Skateboards are prohibited to be ridden in any park except in areas designated and operated as a skate park facility. 
(Ord. No. 2007.11.02, 11-8-2007) 
Sec. 18-60. - Plant material. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dig, cut, bruise, debark or mutilate or cause to be transplanted, cut, bruised, debarked, or mutilated any plant material of all and any description within any recreation area without written permission of the recreation department or its designated official. 
(Code 1975, § 18-35) 
Sec. 18-61. - Advertising; attaching items to plants and structures. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place or erect any structure, sign, bulletin board, poster or advertising device of any kind whatever in any recreation area or to attach any notice, bill, poster, sign, wire, rod, chain, or cord to any tree, shrub, fence railing, post, or structure within any recreation area, except such persons as authorized by the recreation department or its designated official. 
(Code 1975, § 18-26) 
Sec. 18-62. - Selling, peddling, begging. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in soliciting, peddling, begging, selling or plying the vocation of a solicitor, agent, peddler, beggar, or salesman of any description in any recreation area; and it shall be unlawful for any person to sell, hock or vend fruits, candies, popcorn, peanuts, ice cream, soft drinks, and similar merchandise within the recreation area, unless written authority is given by the recreation department or its designated official. 
(Code 1975, § 18-27) 
Cross reference- Itinerant merchants, § 14-151 et seq. 
Sec. 18-63. - Penalty-Banned from use of property. 
(a)  Any person violating the provisions of this division may be banned by the recreation director or his designee from using or going upon the premises of any of the city parks and recreation facilities for a period of ninety (90) days for the first offense, one hundred twenty (120) days for the second offense, and for an indefinite period for any subsequent offense. If the offender is determined to be a probable risk and will be detrimental to the health, welfare, safety and enjoyment of recreation programs of the general public, a first-time offender may be denied the use of city parks and recreation facilities indefinitely. Notice of such determination shall be given in written form to the offender and shall be served upon the person to whom it is directed by either a recreation department employee, an officer of the police department, or by certified mail, return receipt requested, as pleadings and civil cases are served under the North Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure. Provided that any person notified of such ban shall have the right to appeal said decision to the city manager. The decision of the city manager shall be final, except for the rights of the person appealing to the North Carolina Civil Court by petition for certiorari, and that said city manager shall keep a full record of all evidence submitted at said appeal and shall certify the same to the court granting the writ of certiorari. It shall be a misdemeanor for any person who willfully interrupts, disturbs, disrupts or interferes with any program or activity being conducted at a city park or recreation facility and who, upon being directed to leave the park or recreation facility by the recreation director, or the recreation department employee in charge thereof, to willfully refuses to leave the park or facility. 
(b)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Activity as used herein shall include, but not be limited to, the daily work routine of recreation department employees. 
    Disorderly conduct means a public disturbance intentionally caused by any person or group. This can include fighting, acts of vandalism, making or using any utterance, gesture, display or abusive language, using excessively loud or argumentative language, or behavior that is intended to and is likely to provoke a violent retaliation. 
    Fighting means the passing of a blow. 
    Vandalism consists of the willful or malicious destruction, injury, disfigurement or defacement of any real or personal property leased, owned or used, without the consent of the department. 
(Amend. No. 00.4.5, 4-4-2000; Amend. of 5-3-2005) 
Secs. 18-64-18-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT FOR USE OF FACILITIES 

Sec. 18-76. - Required. 
    Before a publicized activity which is not under the programmed or supervised activities of the recreation department can be scheduled at or in any recreation area, a permit must be obtained in accordance with this division. 
Sec. 18-77. - Application. 
    A person seeking issuance of a permit under this division shall file an application with the recreation department. Applications for use of recreation department facilities must be made in person, and in writing, at the recreation department offices. Each application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant group or organization; 
(2)  The name and address of the person, corporation or association sponsoring the activity, if any; 
(3)  The day and hours for which the permit is desired; 
(4)  The recreation area for which such permit is desired; 
(5)  An estimate of the anticipated attendance. 
(Code 1975, § 18-37(a)) 
Sec. 18-78. - Standards for issuance. 
    The director shall issue a permit under this division when he finds that: 
(1)  The proposed activity or use of the recreation area will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from general public employment of the recreation area; 
(2)  The proposed activity or use may not be reasonably anticipated to incite violence, crime or disorderly conduct; 
(3)  The proposed activity and use will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the promotion of public health, welfare, safety and recreation; 
(4)  The proposed activity will not entail unusual, extraordinary or burdensome expense or police operation by the city; 
(5)  The facilities desired have not been reserved for other use at the day and hour required in the application; 
(6)  No commercial, profit-making use is proposed for recreation department buildings or recreation area; except when providing contracted services for the recreation department or for non-recurring events such as tournaments with the proper fees and charges being paid to the department. 
(7)  Recreation buildings are to be used for approved charitable events only, if an admission fee is charged upon approval of the contract for such events by the recreation department; 
(8)  Alcoholic beverages are not permitted in or on recreation department buildings or grounds; 
(9)  Arrangements have been made to clean any kitchen area after use; 
(10)  Persons using recreation department buildings can be held liable for any damage to, or defacing of buildings or the equipment contained therein; 
(11)  All dances and parties close at 11:00 p.m., unless special permission is given for a later hour; 
(12)  Payment for use of the facilities has been made as required in this division. 
(Code 1975, § 18-37(b); Amend. of 5-3-2005) 
Sec. 18-79. - Payment for use of facilities. 
(a)  Payment for use of recreation department buildings shall be made at the recreation department office in advance. 
(b)  A fee for utilities shall be charged for the use of recreational facilities for any official school approved activity of the schools of the city or of the county, or the Boy Scouts or Girl Scouts. 
(c)  All civic clubs shall pay a utilities fee to use the buildings and shall be responsible for leaving the building and grounds in orderly condition. 
(Code 1975, § 18-37(b)) 
Sec. 18-80. - Denial. 
    The director shall deny any application and refuse to issue a permit if the standards set forth in this division are not met. 
(Code 1975, § 18-37(b), (c)) 
Sec. 18-81. - Appeal. 
    Within two (2) days after receipt of an application the director shall appraise an applicant in writing of his reason for refusing a permit, and any aggrieved person shall have the right to appeal in writing within two (2) days to the recreation department, which shall consider the application under the standards set forth in paragraph (2) and sustain or overrule the director's decision within seven (7) days. The decision of the recreation department shall be final. 
(Code 1975, § 18-37(c)) 
Sec. 18-82. - Effect of permit. 
    A permittee shall be bound by all recreation department rules and regulations and all applicable ordinances fully as though the same were inserted in the permit. 
(Code 1975, § 18-37(d)) 
Sec. 18-83. - Liability of permittee. 
    The person to whom a permit is issued shall be liable for any loss, damage or injury sustained by any person whatever, by reason of the negligence of the person to whom the permit is issued. 
(Code 1975, § 18-37(e)) 
Sec. 18-84. - Revocation. 
    The director or a recreation department official shall have the authority to revoke a permit issued under this section upon a finding of violation of any rule or ordinance or upon good cause shown, and to deny the right to use recreation department buildings and areas to individuals or groups not conforming to these rules and regulations. 
(Code 1975, § 18-37(h)) 
Chapter 19 - POLICE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Civil defense, Ch. 7; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, Ch. 16. 
State Law reference- Municipal law enforcement, G.S. § 160A-281 et seq. 

Sec. 19-1. - Composition. 
    The police organization shall consist of the city manager, police chief, and as many police officers as the city council shall determine. 
(Code 1975, § 20-1; Ord. No. 85.8.1, 8-6-85) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to appoint chief of police, G.S. § 160A-281. 
Sec. 19-2. - Powers and duties of police chief. 
    The police chief shall have the following power and duty to: 
(1)  Be chief executive of the police force; 
(2)  Be chargeable with and responsible for the execution of all laws and ordinances and all rules and regulations of the department; 
(3)  Assign to duty the officers and members of the police force and to change such assignments from time to time whenever in his judgment the exigencies of the service may require; and 
(4)  Have general care of the peace of the city and see to it that all subordinates do their duty in preserving such peace. 
(Code 1975, § 20-2) 
Sec. 19-3. - Auxiliary police. 
    There is established within the city police department, as a division thereof, an auxiliary police division. The auxiliary police division shall be a volunteer organization, whose members shall serve without compensation, composed of as many members as may from time to time be determined by the chief of police and approved by the city manager. 
(Code 1975, § 20-3; Ord. No. 85.8.1, 8-6-85; Ord. No. 2006.05.01, 5-1-2006) 
State Law reference- Auxiliary law enforcement personnel, G.S. § 160A-282. 
Sec. 19-4. - Powers of police officers. 
    The police officers shall have authority to arrest all persons for violations of the laws of the state and the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city, and to execute anywhere in the police jurisdiction of the city any warrant or process. If resisted in the discharge of their official duties, the police officers shall have authority to summon and deputize a sufficient number of citizens to aid in enforcing the law. 
(Code 1975, § 20-4) 
State Law reference- Powers and duties of policemen, G.S. § 160A-285. 
Sec. 19-5. - Intergovernmental police assistance-Authority to execute agreements. 
    The chief executive officer of the police force, with the consent of the city manager, is hereby authorized to execute contracts or agreements with such other political subdivisions of the state as to him may seem advisable, pursuant to section 160A-288 of the general statutes, whereby the parties agree to render mutual aid and assistance by the loan of law enforcement officers and equipment in time of emergency, including the prevention, detention or control of civil disorders. Such contracts or agreements shall provide that they shall take effect upon ratification by the governing bodies of each party thereto and recordation in the minutes thereof. 
(Code 1975, § 20-6) 
Sec. 19-6. - Same-Ratification and effective date of agreements. 
    Contracts or agreements under section 19-5 shall specify when they shall take effect and shall be presented to the governing board of each party for ratification at its next regular meeting or at a special meeting called for that purpose, but such contract or agreement executed on behalf of this city shall be in all respects valid and binding on the city between the time of its final execution and the next regular or special meeting of the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 20-7) 
Chapter 20 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings, Ch. 5,; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 15; throwing missiles over streets and sidewalks prohibited, § 16-6; parades and demonstrations, Ch. 17; vehicles for hire, Ch. 21; water and sewers, Ch. 22. 
State Law reference- Special assessments for streets and sidewalks, G.S. § 160A-216 et seq.; streets and sidewalks generally, G.S. § 160A-296 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Littering. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, sweep or leave any trash, paper, refuse or other like substance upon any street, sidewalk or other public place in the city. 
(Code 1975, § 21-4) 
Sec. 20-2. - Planting elm, mulberry or chinaberry trees near streets. 
    It shall be unlawful to plant any elm, mulberry or chinaberry tree within fifty (50) feet of any street. 
(Code 1975, § 21-6) 
Sec. 20-3. - Posting advertisements or signs on utility poles. 
    It shall be unlawful to place, tack or nail any sign or advertising matter on any telegraph, telephone or light pole. 
(Code 1975, § 21-7) 
Sec. 20-4. - Fishing or hunting from dam at south end of fox lake. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fish or hunt, by any means or device, from the dam at the southern extremity of Fox Lake, all of which dam is in the street right-of-way maintained and owned by the city. 
(Ord. No. 88.5.3, 5-3-88) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 88-5-3, adopted May 3, 1988, adding § 21-7a to the 1975 Code, has been included as § 20-4 herein at the editor's discretion. 
Secs. 20-5-20-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Excavating in parks and recreation areas, § 18-58. 
State Law reference- Authority of the city to regulate, license and prohibit digging in the streets, G.S. § 160A-296(6). 

Sec. 20-16. - "Street" defined. 
    As used in this article, the term "street" includes public alleys and sidewalks, as well as roads and streets. 
(Code 1975, § 21-8) 
Sec. 20-17. - Permit-Required. 
    No person shall cut an opening in any street without first obtaining a permit therefor from the director of public works. 
(Code 1975, § 21-9) 
Sec. 20-18. - Same-Liability for damages. 
    The issuance of a permit under this article shall not relieve the person who makes or is responsible for making an opening in the street from liability for any damages that may result from such opening. As a condition of obtaining a permit the applicant shall be required to indemnify and save harmless the city against any damages or liability arising out of or resulting from such opening. 
(Code 1975, § 21-10) 
Sec. 20-19. - Same-Fees. 
    For the privilege of making a street opening, the applicant shall pay a fee to be set from time to time and kept on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 21-11) 
Sec. 20-20. - Pipelaying. 
    Any piping laid within a street shall be laid with its upper surface at least thirty (30) inches below the profile of the street, unless the director of public works determines that this is not feasible. 
(Code 1975, § 21-12) 
Sec. 20-21. - Backfilling. 
    The permittee shall refill any ditch he has dug with sand clay in six-inch layers, and shall tamp each layer thoroughly before the next layer is placed. The ditch shall be filled to a point at least two (2) inches above the finished grade of the street. 
(Code 1975, § 21-13) 
Sec. 20-22. - Safety requirements. 
    No person shall allow any ditch or excavation in a street to remain unattended at any time without proper barricading, nor allow any such ditch or excavation to remain open at night beginning one (1) hour after sunset without displaying thereon signal lights sufficient to warn the public of the ditch or excavation. 
(Code 1975, § 21-14) 
Secs. 20-23-20-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DRIVEWAYS 

Sec. 20-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial or industrial driveway means a driveway providing vehicular ingress and egress to and from property used for purposes other than residential. 
    Residential driveway means a driveway providing vehicular ingress and egress to and from property used for residential purposes. 
    Width, as applied to a driveway, means the width where it crosses an existing sidewalk or area within the technical sidewalk lines as established by the department of engineering. 
(Code 1975, § 21-15) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 20-32. - Permit. 
(a)  Required. No person shall pave a driveway across any public sidewalk, walkway or parkway, or into any street, nor cut any curb for the construction of a driveway, without first having obtained a permit therefor. 
(b)  Fees. Fees for permits shall be set forth in the fee schedule and shall be paid to the director of public works or his designee at the time of issuance of permit. 
(c)  Application. Application for a permit shall be made to the director of public works in duplicate, and shall state among other things the location, grade and dimensions of the proposed driveway and the purpose for which it is desired. Two (2) sets of plans showing all pertinent information shall accompany the application for any commercial or industrial driveways. Plans for residential driveways shall be furnished when requested by the public works director. Applications for permits for driveways on state department of transportation streets shall be made first to the state department of transportation district engineer, located on North Boulevard. 
(d)  Issuance. If the proposed driveway complies with provisions of this section, the director of public works shall issue a permit therefor. 
(e)  Bond. The public works director, with concurrence of the city manager, may require a bond to cover estimated costs of construction of the driveway according to the specifications of this article and the permit. 
(f)  Existing driveways. Existing driveways shall not be relocated, altered or reconstructed without a permit approving the relocation, alteration or reconstruction, and such driveways shall be subject to the limitations set forth in this article. 
(Code 1975, §§ 21-16, 21-17(e); Ord. No. 2006.9.05, 9-5-2006) 
Sec. 20-33. - Standards. 
(a)  Width. 
(1)  The width of a residential driveway shall be no less than ten (10) feet and no more than twenty-four (24) feet. When two (2) residential driveways coincide along a property line, the maximum width shall not exceed twenty-four (24) feet. 
(2)  The width of a commercial or industrial driveway shall be no less than twelve (12) feet and no more than thirty (30) feet. 
(3)  The city engineer may require a decrease or increase in the width of any driveway if it would otherwise create a hazard to pedestrians or traffic. 
(b)  Location and number. 
(1)  The number of driveways serving any property may be limited to one (1) where necessary to decrease traffic and pedestrian hazards, as determined by the city engineer. Where special hazards exist adjacent to a lot abutting on two (2) or more streets, the engineer may require, as a condition of the issuance of a permit to construct driveways for access to such lot, that special review be made of same. 
(2)  The number of driveways serving one (1) business or commercial establishment shall not exceed two (2) from any one (1) street, without special permit. 
(3)  No driveway shall be constructed nearer than twenty (20) feet to any other driveway on the same property, nearer than five (5) feet to any property line except where two (2) residential driveways coincide along a property line, nearer than fifteen (15) feet to the corner of any intersection measured from the right-of-way line, nor nearer than twenty (20) feet to the extended curbline on an intersecting street. 
(c)  Types. 
(1)  Driveways shall be of the standard ramp type, except that street-type entrances may be allowed for entrances into parking lots of planned shopping centers, and entrances from thoroughfares into parking areas for one hundred (100) or more cars. 
(2)  The number and locations of street-type driveway entrances shall be determined by the planning and engineering departments of the city, after taking into consideration traffic volumes, speed, general circulation problems, grades, and any other factors affecting traffic movement in the area. 
(d)  Specifications. 
(1)  All work done in the construction of driveways shall conform to the standard specifications for concrete sidewalks and driveways as established by the city engineer. 
(2)  The sidewalk shall be constructed separately from the driveway which crosses it. All longitudinal and transverse joints of the sidewalk shall be complete joints through the full depth of the slab, and not false joints or markings. 
(3)  No driveway apron shall extend out into the street farther than the face of the curb or the edge of the paving, and under no circumstances shall a driveway apron extend into the gutter area. 
(4)  Every person who intends or plans to use or is now using any portion of a sidewalk as a private driveway shall, if the director of public works certifies that the sidewalk area is inadequate for vehicular traffic, reconstruct the sidewalk in such a manner that it shall be capable of carrying vehicular traffic without creating pedestrian hazards and in accordance with the specifications of this section. 
(Code 1975, § 21-17(a)-(d)) 
Sec. 20-34. - Abandoned driveways. 
    When in the opinion of the city manager or his designees, an existing driveway has been abandoned or is no longer needed to serve abutting property, or when the city council determines that a driveway should be closed in whole or in part, it shall be the duty of the abutting property owner to restore the curbs and sidewalks to the city standards. 
(Code 1975, § 21-18) 
Sec. 20-35. - Appeals. 
    Decisions of the director of public works under this article may be appealed by the applicant in writing to the city manager, whose decision shall be final. 
(Code 1975, § 21-19) 
Secs. 20-36-20-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SIDEWALKS 

Sec. 20-46. - Overhanging shrubbery and hedges. 
    No hedge or shrubbery shall be permitted to overhang any sidewalk. 
(Code 1975, § 21-1) 
Sec. 20-47. - Displaying merchandise. 
    It shall be unlawful for any merchant or salesman to occupy any of the sidewalks or to place goods, wares and merchandise thereon for the purpose of display or sale. Provided, however, that goods, wares and merchandise may be displayed on the city sidewalk in front of any mercantile store so long as four (4) feet of sidewalk space be unobstructed. 
(Code 1975, § 21-2; Ord. No. 95.8.1, 8-1-95) 
Cross reference- Itinerant merchants, § 14-152 et seq. 
Sec. 20-48. - Use by wheeled devices. 
    It shall be unlawful to ride, pull or propel any bicycle, motorcycle, handcart, push cart, skateboard, or any other wheeled contrivance, other than baby carriages or invalid chairs prescribed by a physician or health officer, upon the city sidewalks; and it shall be unlawful to ride, pull, or propel upon the municipal parking lots any skate boards or other wheeled contrivances, other than a bicycle, moped, or motor vehicle as defined by Chapter 20 of the North Carolina General Statutes. 
(Code 1975, § 21-3; Ord. No. 97.6.3, 5-20-97) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 15. 
Sec. 20-49. - Removal of obstructions.. 
    The owner or occupant of any dwelling or premises shall keep the sidewalks adjacent to the premises clear of rubbish, dirt, weeds, trash or other obstructions. 
(Code 1975, § 21-5) 
Cross reference- Garbage and trash generally, Ch. 11) 
Sec. 20-50. - Notice to abate nuisance. 
    Whenever it shall come to the attention of any code enforcement officer or city manager that any of the conditions prevail set forth in section 20-49, the inspector or city manager shall forthwith give the owner and occupant notice thereof to abate or remove the conditions or otherwise comply with this section within seven (7) days. In the event of immediate detriment to human safety or welfare, the inspector or city manager may take appropriate action to summarily abate the condition without notice. 
(Ord. No. 02.10.2, 10-1-2002) 
Sec. 20-51. - Process to create lien on property. 
(a)  In the event of a violation of section 20-49, the owner, occupant or agent of the lot or premises shall be notified to remove the cause of the violation at his expense within a time specified in the notice. Such notice shall be served by a police officer by delivering a copy thereof to the owner, occupant or agent of such property or by mailing a copy thereof by certified mail. If there be no owner or agent upon whom the notice can be served, then the police officer shall post a written or printed notice upon the property or premises, setting forth that unless the nuisance is removed or abated within a time specified in the notice, the same will be abated at the expense of the owner, occupant, or agent. The notice shall also state that any owner, occupant or agent of either within forty-eight (48) hours of personal service, excluding non-business days, or within ninety-six (96) hours of posting of the notice upon the property or premises or of mailing said notice, may request verbally or in writing for a hearing before the director of public works and the director of public works shall within forty-eight (48) hours from receipt of the demand for said hearing, conduct a hearing to determine whether or not said vacant lot or other premises is a nuisance as defined in section 20-49. 
(Ord. No. 02.10.2, 10-1-2002) 
Chapter 20.5 - TREES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Recreational facilities regulations, 18-46 et seq.; planting trees near streets, 20-2; overhanging hedges on sidewalk, 20-46. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 20.5-1-20.5-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREET TREES 

Sec. 20.5-20. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this ordinance is to regulate the planting, maintenance and removal of trees on municipally owned public property and rights-of-way within the city and on municipally owned property wherever located. In order to protect and conserve trees on public property and rights-of-way, this ordinance provides for the pruning, treatment and removal of trees and shrubs as is deemed necessary by the city council or a person acting under the authority of the city council. This article is also intended to provide for the trimming or removal of trees on public land when they obscure street lights, interfere with utility lines, or constitute a hazard to pedestrian or vehicular traffic, or otherwise endanger the public health, safety or welfare. 
    Another purpose of this article is to encourage the protection of trees and express the city's intent to use trees to create a more natural and amenable human environment. This article is not intended to be punitive nor to cause hardship to any person who uses the utmost care and diligence to protect trees within the city or on city property. 
(Ord. of 5-7-91, § 1) 
Sec. 20.5-21. - Definitions. 
    Trees are woody plants at least fifteen (15) feet tall at maturity, with a well-developed crown and a trunk of at least several inches in diameter. 
(Ord. of 5-7-91, § 2) 
Sec. 20.5-22. - Creation and establishment of a city tree board. 
    There is hereby created and established a city tree board for the city. The duties of the tree board are assigned to the environmental affairs board. 
(Ord. of 5-7-91, § 3) 
Sec. 20.5-23. - Term of office. 
    The term of office shall be the same as the term of office of the members of the environmental affairs board. In the event that a vacancy shall occur during the term of any member, his successor shall be appointed for the unexpired portion of the term. 
(Ord. of 5-7-91, § 4) 
Sec. 20.5-24. - Compensation. 
    Members of the board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. of 5-7-91, § 5) 
Sec. 20.5-25. - Duties and Responsibilities. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the tree board to study, investigate, counsel, and develop and/or update annually, and administer a written plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or disposition of trees and shrubs in parks, along streets and in other public areas. Such plan will be presented annually to the city council and upon its acceptance and approval shall constitute the official comprehensive city tree plan for the city. 
    The tree board, when requested by the city council, shall consider, investigate, make finding, report and recommend upon any special matter of question coming within the scope of its work. 
(Ord. of 5-7-91, § 6) 
Sec. 20.5-26. - Operation. 
    The mayor or a member of the city council appointed by the mayor shall serve as liaison between the tree board and the city council. 
    In the event of an emergency where the situation requires immediate action, the mayor and city manager shall have the authority to authorize corrective action, and a report of the action shall be made to the tree board at its next regular meeting. 
(Ord. of 5-7-91, § 7) 
Sec. 20.5-27. - Street tree species to be planted. 
    The recommended street trees for North Carolina printed by Natural Resources and Community Development Division of Forest Resource with the addition of White Oak, White Ash, and Photina shall constitute the official street tree species for the city. No species other than those included in this list may be planted as street trees without written permission of the city tree board. 
(Ord. of 5-7-91, § 8) 
Sec. 20.5-28. - Spacing. 
    The spacing of street trees will be in accordance with the three species size classes listed in section 20.5-27 of this article, and no trees may be planted closer together than the following: small trees, thirty (30) feet; medium trees, forty (40) feet; and large trees, fifty (50) feet; except in special plantings designed or approved by a landscape architect. 
(Ord. of 5-7-91, § 9) 
Sec. 20.5-29. - Distance from curb and sidewalk. 
    The distance trees may be planted from curbs and sidewalks will be in accordance with the tree species size classes listed in section 20.5-27 of this article, and no trees may be planted closer to any curb or sidewalk than the following: small trees, two (2) feet; medium trees, three (3) feet; and large trees, four (4) feet. Where there is no existing curb, the distance shall be increased by two (2) feet. 
(Ord. of 5-7-91, § 10) 
Sec. 20.5-30. - Distance from street corners and fireplugs. 
    No street tree shall be planted closer than thirty-five (35) feet of any street corner, measured from the point of nearest intersecting curb or curb lines. No street tree shall be planted closer than ten (10) feet of any fireplug. 
(Ord. of 5-7-91, § 11) 
Sec. 20.5-31. - Utilities. 
    No street trees other than those species listed as small trees in section 20.5-27 of this article may be planted under or within ten (10) lateral feet of any overhead utility wire, or over or within five (5) lateral feet of any underground water line, sewer line, transmission line or other utility. 
(Ord. of 5-7-91, § 12) 
Sec. 20.5-32. - Public tree care. 
    The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares, and public grounds, as may be necessary to insure public safety and to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. The city tree board may remove or cause or order to be removed, any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines, or other public improvements, or is affected with any injurious fungus, insects or other pest. This section does not prohibit the planting of street trees by adjacent property owners providing that the selection and location of such trees is in accordance with sections 20.5-27 through 20.5-31 of this article. 
(Ord. of 5-7-91, § 13) 
Sec. 20.5-33. - Tree topping. 
    It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm, or city department to top any street tree, park tree, or other tree on public property. Topping is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three inches in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempted from this ordinance at the determination of the city tree board. 
(Ord. of 5-7-91, § 14) 
Sec. 20.5-34. - Pruning, corner clearance. 
    Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the city shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not obstruct the light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of eight (8) feet above the surface of the street or sidewalk. Those owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, broken or decayed limbs which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The city shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a street light or interferes with visibility of any traffic control device or sign. 
(Ord. of 5-7-91, § 15) 
Sec. 20.5-35. - Dead or diseased tree removal on private property. 
    The city shall have the right to cause the removal of any dead or diseased trees on private property within the city, when such trees constitute a hazard to life and property, or harbor insects or diseases which constitute a potential threat to other trees within the city. The city tree board will notify in writing the owners of such trees. Removal shall be done by said owners at their own expense within sixty (60) days after the date of service of notice. In the event of failure of owners to comply with such provisions, the city shall have the authority to remove such trees and charge to cost of removal on the owners property tax notice. 
(Ord. of 5-7-91, § 16) 
Sec. 20.5-36. - Removal of stumps. 
    All stumps of street and park trees shall be removed below the surface of the ground so that the top of the stump shall not project above the surface of the ground. 
(Ord. of 5-7-91, § 17) 
Sec. 20.5-37. - Interference with city tree board. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the city tree board, or any of its agents, while engaging in and about the planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying, or removing of any street trees, park trees, or trees on private grounds, as authorized by this article. 
(Ord. of 5-7-91, § 18) 
Sec. 20.5-38. - Arborists license and bond. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or firm to engage in the business or occupation of pruning, treating, or removing street or park trees within the city without first applying for and procuring a license. The license fee shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) annually in advance; provided, however, that no license shall be required of any public service company or city employee doing such work in the pursuit of their public service endeavors. Before any license shall be issued, each applicant shall first file evidence of possession of liability insurance in the minimum amounts of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for bodily injury and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for property damage indemnifying the city or any person injured or damaged resulting from the pursuit of such endeavors as herein described. 
(Ord. of 5-7-91, § 19) 
Sec. 20.5-39. - Review by city council. 
    The city council shall have the right to review the conduct, acts and decisions of the city tree board. Any person may appeal from any ruling or order of the city tree board to the city council who may hear the matter and make final decision. 
(Ord. of 5-7-91, § 20) 
Sec. 20.5-40. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be upon conviction or plea of guilty, subject to a fine not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) or thirty (30) days in jail or both. 
(Ord. of 5-7-91, § 21) 
Chapter 21 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2010.11.02, adopted Nov. 3, 2010, amended Ch. 21 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 21, §§ 21-1-21-5, pertained to the same subject matter, and derived from Code 1975, §§ 23-1-23-5 and Ord. No. 89.12.1, adopted Dec. 5, 1989. 
Cross reference- Privilege license for taxis, § 14-127; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 15; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 20. 
State Law reference- Municipal regulation of taxicabs and other vehicles for hire, G.S. § 160A-304. 

Sec. 21-1. - Owner's permit. 
(a)  Every person engaged in the business of operating a taxicab/commercial limousine/shuttle within the corporate limits of the city or between the limits of the city and any point within five (5) miles of the limits of the city shall first secure an owner's permit for each vehicle so operated. The owner's permit for such vehicles shall be obtained from the police chief, after the approval of the application therefor by the police chief and upon the payment of an annual fee for each vehicle, to be sent from time to time and kept on file in the office of the city clerk. The permit shall run for one (1) year from the first day of July of each year; and the fee therefor shall not be apportioned if the permit is obtained for a part of the year. 
(b)  A taxicab/commercial limousine/shuttle licensed by the state and regularly garaged and operated in another municipality may make a trip to or through the city for a purpose other than picking up a fare without thereby becoming subject to this section. 
(Ord. No. 2010.11.02, 11-3-2010) 
State Law reference- License tax limited, G.S. § 20-97. 
Sec. 21-2. - Financial responsibility. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a taxicab/commercial limousine/shuttle within the city or to permit anyone to operate a vehicle owned by him without being in compliance with G.S. ch. 20 § 280, or its successor. 
(b)  Each policy required by G.S. ch. 20 § 280 shall be filed with the police chief along with the application for an owner's permit; and the filing and maintaining of such policy in force shall be a condition precedent to the operation of a taxicab/commercial limousine/shuttle within the corporate limits. 
(c)  Notice of this section shall be given by the owner to each insurer, and the insurer or owner shall give the police chief five (5) days' notice prior to the cancellation of any policy required by this section. 
(d)  Each policy shall be effective, unless cancelled after notice, as above stated, for a period covering the period for which the license is issued. 
(Ord. No. 2010.11.02, 11-3-2010) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to license, regulate and control taxicab drivers, G.S. § 20-37; similar provisions, G.S. § 160A-304(a). 
Sec. 21-3. - Driver's permit. 
(a)  No person shall drive a vehicle for hire as a taxicab/commercial limousine/shuttle without a driver's permit issued pursuant to this section. No person who owns or has authority and control over a vehicle shall permit any other person to drive the vehicle for hire as a taxicab/commercial limousine/shuttle unless that person has such a permit. 
(b)  Application for a permit under this section shall be made to the police chief, who may deny the application for a good cause, but who shall otherwise issue a permit upon payment of the license fee and the giving of the oath required in subsection (d). The application for a permit shall include a fingerprint card containing the fingerprints of the applicant made by and under the supervision of the police department. 
(c)  The permit fee shall be set from time to time and shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(d)  Every applicant shall show under oath that he has not within the last two (2) years of the date of the application: 
(1)  Been convicted of violation of any federal or state law relating to the possession for sale or sale of any intoxicating liquor or barbiturate drugs; 
(2)  Been addicted to or a habitual user of intoxicating liquors or narcotic or barbiturate drugs; 
(3)  Been in violation of any federal or state law relating to prostitution; nor 
(4)  Been a habitual violator of traffic laws or ordinances. 
Any permit issued upon a false oath by an applicant will be immediately revoked upon receipt of evidence of a falsity thereof. 
(e)  Any permit issued under this section may be revoked at any time by the police chief upon a showing that, because of occurrences after the issuance of the permit, the permittee could not at that time truthfully give the oath required in this section. 
(Ord. No. 2010.11.02, 11-3-2010) 
Sec. 21-4. - Rates to be posted. 
    Every taxicab/commercial limousine/shuttle licensed under this chapter shall carry a sign, clearly visible to passengers, stating the rates or fares charged for the use of the vehicle; and it shall be unlawful for any taxicab/commercial limousine/shuttle to be operated without such a sign, or for any person to charge a fare in excess of the rate stated on the sign. 
(Ord. No. 2010.11.02, 11-3-2010) 
Sec. 21-5. - Regular stands; cruising. 
    Every owner of a taxicab/commercial limousine/shuttle licensed under this chapter shall maintain within the city a regular stand or station from which the taxicab/commercial limousine/shuttle shall be operated. Every such owner shall post at the station or stand a sign in letters clearly visible for a distance of ten (10) feet stating the name of the owner of the vehicle and the hours during the day and night during which such vehicle is available for public rental. During such hours, except when actually answering a call or when going to or returning from a call, every vehicle so licensed shall remain at such stand or station; and it shall be unlawful for any taxicab/commercial limousine/shuttle operated within the corporate limits to cruise in search of passengers or for any other reason. 
(Ord. No. 2010.11.02, 11-3-2010) 
Chapter 22 - WATER AND SEWERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings, Ch. 5; housing, Ch. 12; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 20. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to construct, operate, etc., water supply and distribution systems, sewage collection systems, etc., G.S. § 160A-312. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City right-of-way means the dedicated boundaries of a street or utility easement. 
    Improved street means any street having a wearing surface of concrete, asphalt, brick, stone block, tar treatment or similar hard material. 
    Lateral means a pipe connecting a sanitary sewer or water main with the line of adjacent property or extending from the main to the city right-of-way line. 
    Macadam street means any street with crushed stone surface, either water, asphalt or tar bound. 
    Sewer means any sanitary sewer. 
    Unincorporated street means any street having a dirt surface. 
(Code 1975, § 24-1) 
Sec. 22-2. - Application of chapter to certain contracts. 
    All pertinent provisions of this chapter are hereby made a part of the terms and conditions under which the city furnishes sewer or water service to any person, makes any sewer or water connection or performs work of any kind in connection with the furnishing of sewer or water service. 
(Code 1975, § 24-2) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-3. - Water and sewer charges; water and sewer tap fees. 
    Water and sewer charges and water and sewer tap fees shall be established from time to time by the city council by fee schedule, and such fees and charges shall be maintained on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 24-17; Ord. No. 02.8.2, 8-6-2002) 
Sec. 22-4. - Development fees. 
(a)  General principles. The planning and extensions of the water and sewer system of the city shall be accomplished in accordance with the following general principles: 
(1)  Extensions shall be made in a manner so as to promote the orderly growth of the community without regard to city boundaries. 
(2)  Water and sewer development fees shall be established to aid in the financing of new major sewage collection facilities and major water mains and the replacement or enlargement of existing facilities. This charge shall apply uniformly to all properties to which service is extended. 
(3)  The city shall be responsible for the maintenance, operation and control of all sewage and water facilities. 
(b)  Basic policy. Each developer of land shall be responsible for providing water and sewer line connection between his property and an approved public water and/or sewer disposal system. The developer may be reimbursed for that portion of the cost of off-site facilities or on-site facilities of a regional nature which is in excess of, development fees, such reimbursement to come from development fees levied against property developed subsequent to the installation of his connection and utilizing said connection. 
(c)  Financing extensions. 
(1)  Major water and sewer line development fees. Development fee charges shall be collected by method and amount as stated in the City of Clinton Fee Schedule. The water and sewer development fees shall be collected by the city before permission is granted to connect sewer and water lines serving any property with water and sewer facilities of the city. The schedule of charges shall be as follows: 
a.  There shall be a charge for connecting with the water system of the city, either within or without the corporate limits, as contained in the City of Clinton Fee Schedule. 
b.  There shall be a charge for connecting with the sewer system of the city, either within or without the corporate limits, as contained in the City of Clinton Fee Schedule. 
c.  Development fees shall not be imposed upon the following: 
1.  Property which is actually tapped onto the city utility system and which is actually using such system. 
2.  Any usable utility line in existence in a street, adjacent to or within property to be connected with said system which was in place prior to November 1, 2007. (A usable utility line does not include outfalls or water lines where direct service taps are not permitted.) 
3.  Any other areas for which separate utility contracts have been made between the city and developers. 
(2)  Subdivisions. With respect to the installation and financing of water and sewer lines to serve subdivisions the following policies shall apply: 
a.  Specifications. All installations shall be made according to specifications of the city, including the size of the lines, their locations, grade and materials used. 
b.  Ownership and control. All lines constructed and connected with the facilities of the city under these policies shall become property of the city upon completion and at the end of the one (1) year contractor's warranty period. The city shall have exclusive control of all such lines and shall be responsible for their maintenance, repair and operation after the lines are dedicated to and accepted by the city council. 
c.  Contracts. All installations made under a reimbursement agreement shall be accomplished under contracts let after the receipt of sealed competitive bids. The city shall exercise general supervision over the letting of such contracts in order to assure the securing of free competition on such contracts. Should developers wish to enter into contracts on a private basis for constructing improvements, the city reserves the right to make reimbursement only to the amounts as established by competitive bidding or similar work to be done under similar conditions. The city shall have final control in such instances. 
d.  Reimbursement policy. 
1.  A reimbursement agreement shall be entered into between the city and each party installing water and/or sewer lines under the reimbursement policy. Only those lift or pumping stations as may be expressly referred to and covered by a written contract between the developer and the city shall be considered as coming within the reimbursement policy of the town. 
2.  The cost of installing all lines within a subdivision or on property being connected, and the cost of installing all lines between such subdivision or property being developed and the existing lines of the city, shall be borne by the property being so connected. 
3.  Lines subject to reimbursement shall be those lines which are greater than that required for the project being developed. As to such lines, the city will reimburse the developer for the actual extra costs incurred by installing lines in excess of the needs of the property being developed, as determined by the city engineer. In no instance shall the city reimburse for water and sewer lines eight inches or less in size. Reimbursement will be made in no more than ten equal annual installments provided, that the city council may, in its discretion, make such reimbursement in full at any time. 
(d)  Costs and charges. Costs and charges fixed for water and sewer line connections designated in this section shall be in addition to all other charges prescribed by ordinance or resolution now or hereafter in effect by the town. 
(Ord. No. 2007.11.04, 11-8-2007) 
Sec. 22-5. - Fire service availability fee. 
    A base charge shall apply to the entire city with separate water services dedicated to fire protection systems. 
(Ord. No. 2007.11.04, 11-8-2007) 
Secs. 22-6-22-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LATERALS 

Sec. 22-16. - Laying. 
    Water or sewer laterals laid as a part of any water or sewer main improvement shall be laid only within the city right of way, unless in the resolution ordering the improvement, the city specifically directs otherwise. 
(Code 1975, § 24-3) 
Sec. 22-17. - Extending. 
    After laterals are laid from water or sewer mains to the city right-of-way no such lateral shall be extended to the property line until the owner or occupant of the property to be served thereby applies for such an extension. 
(Code 1975, § 24-4) 
Sec. 22-18. - Construction by city only. 
    The construction of laterals for the connection of sewer or water pipes on any lot with sewer or water pipes in a street and the necessary excavation therefor shall be done only by the city. 
(Code 1975, § 24-5) 
Secs. 22-19-22-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 22-31. - Required. 
    Within ninety (90) days after a water main in any street is completed and ready for use, the owner of every abutting lot whereon water may be needed for human use shall cause the lot to be connected with the water main. Within ninety (90) days after a sewer main in any street is completed and ready for use, all owners of every abutting lot having improvements thereon shall cause all water closets, bathtubs, lavatories, sinks and drains upon the lot to be connected with the sewer main; provided, however, the use of septic tanks and seepage lines in operation prior to annexation may be continued until such time as the system becomes in need of repair; provided further that the use of private wells in operation prior to annexation may be continued until such time they become so deficient that they must be replaced by new wells; and provided further that no property owner may make or cause to be made any repair to any private septic tank, seepage line, or private well, without a permit from the building inspector. 
(Code 1975, § 24-6; Ord. No. 90.2.2, 2-6-90) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to require connection, G.S. § 160A-317. 
Sec. 22-32. - Written application. 
    No connection shall be made to any sewer or water main or to any sewer or water lateral except after the written application therefor has been approved by the building inspector. 
(Code 1975, § 24-7) 
Sec. 22-33. - Approval of application. 
    Every application for a water or sewer connection under this chapter shall be approved by the building inspector, unless the connection applied for is of such size or is so located that it cannot be made without impairing the city's ordinary sewer and water service. 
(Code 1975, § 24-8) 
Sec. 22-34. - Duties of city. 
    Upon approval of any application for sewer or water connection, the city shall do the excavating, lay the pipe, install a meter where necessary, make the connection to the main, fill the excavation and replace the surface of the street. 
(Code 1975, § 24-9) 
Sec. 22-35. - Sewer connections. 
    Every sewer connection made directly to a main shall be made at the Y (combination cleanout) provided for the lot to be served. But if no such Y (combination cleanout) has been provided for such lot, then such connection may be made directly to the main at any convenient point. 
(Code 1975, § 24-10) 
Sec. 22-36. - Maintenance and repair. 
    For the purpose of this section the word "connection" shall be construed to mean that portion of water or sewer pipe between the main and the property line. Water connections shall be kept in repair by the city and at the expense of the city. Necessary renewals of water connections shall be made by the city. Sewer connections shall be maintained and repaired by the city at its own expense. Necessary renewals of sewer connections shall be made by the city at a rate set from time to time by the city council, a schedule of which rates is kept on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 24-11) 
Sec. 22-37. - Connections of city water system to other sources of water. 
    No part of the city's water system shall be connected to any source of water supply other than the city's. 
(Code 1975, § 24-12) 
Sec. 22-38. - Outside city limits. 
    No connection of any water or sewer line or system outside the city shall be made to any part of the city's water or sewer system without special permission from the council and on such terms as the council shall prescribe. It shall be the policy of the city to restrict the extension of the city's water and sewer service to only those areas that are located in the city's extraterritorial planning jurisdiction or which has been annexed by satellite annexation. 
(Code 1975, § 24-13; Amend. No. 95.1.1, 1-3-95) 
Sec. 22-39. - Hydraulic elevators and motors. 
    Air chambers of adequate size shall be provided for hydraulic elevators and hydraulic motors in water and sewer connections. The hydraulic elevators and hydraulic motors shall be kept in good repair and working condition. The owner or operator of every such hydraulic elevator or motor shall provide therefor a suitable meter, which shall be maintained in good repair and shall not be removed or replaced except upon notice to the city. 
(Code 1975, § 24-14) 
Sec. 22-40. - Equipment to be property of city. 
    All meters, meter boxes, pipes and other equipment furnished and used by the city in installing any water or sewer connection shall be and remain the property of the city. ; 
(Code 1975, § 24-15) 
Sec. 22-41. - Maintenance of meters. 
    All water and sewer meters, except such as are required to be furnished by certain users of water, shall be kept in good repair and working order by the city and at the expense of the city. Meters furnished by certain users of water shall be kept in good repair and working order by the city, but the expense thereof shall be borne by such users. 
(Code 1975, § 24-16) 
Sec. 22-42. - Irrigation meters. 
    Effective January 1, 2009, all new in-ground irrigation systems connected to the city's water system must be metered separately from primary water supply. 
(Ord. No. 2008.11.3, 11-5-2008) 
Secs. 22-43-22-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WATER SERVICE 

Sec. 22-51. - Water to be sold by measure. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, all water shall be sold by measure, for which purpose the city will install and maintain a proper meter; but the right is reserved by the city to omit such meter for such a period as it may deem desirable, in which event the service shall be paid for at the minimum rate. 
(Code 1975, § 24-18) 
Sec. 22-52. - Application for service. 
    Every application for water service must be made by the owner of the property to be benefitted or his authorized agent according to the form prescribed. 
(Code 1975, § 24-19) 
Sec. 22-53. - City to deliver water to right-of-way. 
    Unless otherwise provided in this article, the city will furnish all material and labor necessary to deliver water from the main to the city right-of-way and all material shall remain the property of the city and will be maintained by the city. All work and material beyond this point shall be furnished by the applicant and shall be maintained by the applicant. 
(Code 1975, § 24-20) 
Sec. 22-54. - City to furnish meters and certain apparatus. 
    The city shall furnish the meter and meter box necessary in connection with the delivery of water service. The city shall also install an appropriate tapping saddle or sleeve at the main, as well as an appropriate value or curb stop at the meter. 
(Code 1975, § 24-21) 
Sec. 22-55. - City to make all taps. 
    No person but an authorized employee of the city shall tap any water main or distributing pipe; nor may anyone not so authorized open or close any valve on the system or open or close any stopcock at the curb on any water service connection. 
(Code 1975, § 24-22) 
Sec. 22-56. - Customer's stop and waste cock. 
    Each water service shall be provided by the consumer with a separate stop and waste cock, to be used by consumer as a shut-off in case of accident or need. All piping, if of iron or steel, shall be full card weight and well galvanized. 
(Code 1975, § 24-23) 
Sec. 22-57. - Separate connections. 
(a)  Only one (1) party shall be served with water through each curb cutoff; and each service shall be made through a separate tap, except for tenement houses and businesses in the central business district where single services and meters may be used. The minimum rate for such service, however, will be the same as for separate users; provided, that separate buildings used in connection with one another in the providing of medical services or public housing to the public and owned or operated by a municipal or nonprofit corporation shall be exempted from the provisions of the section if the city building inspector is of the opinion that the joint use of one (1) curb cutoff and separate tap by such separate buildings does not endanger the safety or health of such buildings, users of such buildings or any other properties or persons. There shall be exempt from this subsection all lodgings located in any commercial, business or manufacturing building which are inhabited by persons who are required to live in said lodgings for the purpose of providing security to the building in which the lodgings are located and any building that is appurtenant to or a part of the business, commercial or manufacturing activity for which the building containing said lodgings is used. 
(b)  One (1) or more multiple dwelling buildings located on contiguous lands with common ownership may be served by a single master water meter. The rate charged for the water used under such service, however, shall be the minimum rate charged for each separate dwelling unit, or the rate charged for the amount of water actually measured through such meter, whichever is greater. 
(Code 1975, § 24-24; Ord. No. 98.1.2, 1-6-98; Ord. No. 60.12.04, 12-12-2006) 
Sec. 22-58. - Inspections. 
    Whenever water is introduced into any premises, or changes which affect the water supply are made in water pipe or fixtures, the plumber shall make a report to the plumbing inspector as soon as the work is completed, whereupon the plumbing will be inspected. No water shall be turned on permanently until the inspector is satisfied that each and every rule relating to the subject has been complied with. 
(Code 1975, § 24-25) 
Sec. 22-59. - Right of access for inspection. 
    The city reserves the right for its inspector to enter the premises of any consumer for the purpose of inspection at any reasonable time to ascertain that no water is being wasted and that the prescribed regulations are being complied with. 
(Code 1975, § 24-26) 
Sec. 22-60. - Cutting off service. 
    The city reserves the right to cut off any water service in emergencies or in cases of failure to comply with the prescribed regulations. 
(Code 1975, § 24-27) 
Sec. 22-61. - Interference with waterworks; unauthorized use of water. 
    It shall be unlawful to interfere in any way with any of the buildings, wells, reservoirs, tanks, pipes, meters or connections or with the water in them or with any apparatus forming a part of the waterworks system; to make any connection therewith, except as provided in this article; to knowingly permit another to do so on their premises or premises in their possession or control, or to knowingly use water from such unauthorized connection. Neither shall any authorized consumer be allowed to supply water to other persons or families nor take or carry away water from any such authorized connection or from any hydrant, watering trough, or public fountain, without the consent of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 24-28) 
Sec. 22-62. - Customer deposits-When required. 
(a)  Residential. A deposit shall be required of all persons occupying but not owning premises for which a water or sewer connection is made for residential purposes. The amount of such deposit shall be set from time to time by the council and a schedule shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  Business. A deposit shall be required of all persons occupying but not owning premises for which a water or sewer connection is made for business purposes. The amount of such deposit shall be set from time to time by the council and a schedule shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 24-29) 
Sec. 22-63. - Same-Disposition.
